profile.name: Céki

title: HOLY HANNAH. Easily one of the most spine-tingling, bone-chilling books I've ever read.
body: HOLY. FREAKING. HANNAH. Five stars and some fireworks for good measure. Hoover is a master at writing an evil antagonist and nailing character voice.  I hadn’t had the opportunity to read Verity until this past weekend when some Twitter friends and I agreed to read it together so we could talk about it after (and boy do I need to talk about this after!) This book was so dark and disturbing!  The first line was top-notch. Like… what an opener! It immediately draws you in and doesn’t let go. It puts you straight into the action and leaves your mind spinning, in this case after just fourteen words. Mind. Blown.  Verity is an example of a story within a story. The main character, Lowen, is an author—and don’t let that cliché fool you. This book was written astonishingly well. Lowen is hired as a co-writer to a hugely famous author, Verity Crawford, who is incapacitated and cannot finish out the remaining three of her six book deal. Lowen must get inside Verity’s head somehow so she can write the last three books as closely to her writing style and authorial voice as possible. To do that, she’s invited to stay at Verity’s house with her husband, Jeremy, and son, Crew, to go through her office and study her notes.  But Lowen finds a manuscript… an autobiography of sorts… and she learns much more about Verity than she ever thought she would—or wanted to. It’s a deeply personal and intimate account of big life events and the things that led up to them. And the more Lowen reads, the more she’s disturbed. And what’s more, she starts experiencing really creepy things around the house that make her question not only Verity’s sanity, but also her own. By the end of the story, I was blown away.  The twists at the end of this book are incredible!  By the time I was finished reading, my jaw was dropped, my eyes were bulging out of their sockets, and I just wanted to talk about it, but it was 2am! I now know what everyone else was talking about when they said this book is bone-chilling and dark. I highlighted so many lines that stuck out, and there’s one in particular in Verity’s biography that will stay with me (but I’m not going to tell you what it is!)  The character voice was strong, the line-level writing was superb, and I was thoroughly disquieted (and I mean that in the best possible way, because I love dark thrillers!)  The ending will have you questioning everything, and I absolutely love books that do that. Stories that make me think about them long after I’ve read the last word on the page.  I absolutely recommend this book to any fellow dark and disturbing thriller lovers. But be forewarned: when I say it’s disturbing… I mean it’s disturbing, especially as a mother. And as someone who lived with a sociopath for almost a decade, there are some eerily familiar feelings I experienced while reading.  Colleen Hoover is a new-to-me author, and I will not hesitate to read more of her books.
body_html:
HOLY. FREAKING. HANNAH. Five stars and some fireworks for good measure. Hoover is a master at writing an evil antagonist and nailing character voice.

I hadn’t had the opportunity to read Verity until this past weekend when some Twitter friends and I agreed to read it together so we could talk about it after (and boy do I need to talk about this after!) This book was so dark and disturbing!

The first line was top-notch. Like… what an opener! It immediately draws you in and doesn’t let go. It puts you straight into the action and leaves your mind spinning, in this case after just fourteen words. Mind. Blown.

Verity is an example of a story within a story. The main character, Lowen, is an author—and don’t let that cliché fool you. This book was written astonishingly well. Lowen is hired as a co-writer to a hugely famous author, Verity Crawford, who is incapacitated and cannot finish out the remaining three of her six book deal. Lowen must get inside Verity’s head somehow so she can write the last three books as closely to her writing style and authorial voice as possible. To do that, she’s invited to stay at Verity’s house with her husband, Jeremy, and son, Crew, to go through her office and study her notes.

But Lowen finds a manuscript… an autobiography of sorts… and she learns much more about Verity than she ever thought she would—or wanted to. It’s a deeply personal and intimate account of big life events and the things that led up to them. And the more Lowen reads, the more she’s disturbed. And what’s more, she starts experiencing really creepy things around the house that make her question not only Verity’s sanity, but also her own. By the end of the story, I was blown away.

The twists at the end of this book are incredible!

By the time I was finished reading, my jaw was dropped, my eyes were bulging out of their sockets, and I just wanted to talk about it, but it was 2am! I now know what everyone else was talking about when they said this book is bone-chilling and dark. I highlighted so many lines that stuck out, and there’s one in particular in Verity’s biography that will stay with me (but I’m not going to tell you what it is!)

The character voice was strong, the line-level writing was superb, and I was thoroughly disquieted (and I mean that in the best possible way, because I love dark thrillers!)

The ending will have you questioning everything, and I absolutely love books that do that. Stories that make me think about them long after I’ve read the last word on the page.

I absolutely recommend this book to any fellow dark and disturbing thriller lovers. But be forewarned: when I say it’s disturbing… I mean it’s disturbing, especially as a mother. And as someone who lived with a sociopath for almost a decade, there are some eerily familiar feelings I experienced while reading.

Colleen Hoover is a new-to-me author, and I will not hesitate to read more of her books.

profile.name: Allison Stevenson

title: An atmospheric, psychological thriller
body: But there is no light where we’re going. This is your final warning. Darkness ahead.  Lowen Ashleigh is a struggling writer on the cusp of financial ruin when she accepts an offer to complete the remaining books in a successful series from best-selling author Verity Crawford. Lowen arrives at Verity's home to her husband, Jeremy, and young son, Crew, to sort through her office filled with notes and outlines. But what she doesn't expect to find is an unfinished autobiography filled with truths Verity never intended anyone to read. Truths such as what really happened the night that her daughter died. Lowen initially keeps the manuscript from Jeremy, but when her feelings for Jeremy continue to grow, she starts to wonder if she's making the write decision.  I feel like I'm falling victim to a lot of books lately the the internet loves that I am slightly disappointed by. Verity was good and twisty and exciting and I think that if you've never read anything like this, it would be incredible, but I don't think it necessarily holds up to other books in the same genre.  However, the story IS really good, it's interesting and intriguing. I love the twist of only getting one person's side of a story. I love that you don't get the full picture from an omniscient narrator, it adds to the psychological aspect of it, it adds to the thrill.  The one thing I really really loved was the ending. What is the truth? What is truth?  No matter which way I look at it, it’s clear that Verity was a master at manipulating the truth. The only question that remains is: Which truth was she manipulating?
body_html:
But there is no light where we’re going. This is your final warning. Darkness ahead.

Lowen Ashleigh is a struggling writer on the cusp of financial ruin when she accepts an offer to complete the remaining books in a successful series from best-selling author Verity Crawford. Lowen arrives at Verity's home to her husband, Jeremy, and young son, Crew, to sort through her office filled with notes and outlines. But what she doesn't expect to find is an unfinished autobiography filled with truths Verity never intended anyone to read. Truths such as what really happened the night that her daughter died. Lowen initially keeps the manuscript from Jeremy, but when her feelings for Jeremy continue to grow, she starts to wonder if she's making the write decision.

I feel like I'm falling victim to a lot of books lately the the internet loves that I am slightly disappointed by. Verity was good and twisty and exciting and I think that if you've never read anything like this, it would be incredible, but I don't think it necessarily holds up to other books in the same genre.

However, the story IS really good, it's interesting and intriguing. I love the twist of only getting one person's side of a story. I love that you don't get the full picture from an omniscient narrator, it adds to the psychological aspect of it, it adds to the thrill.

The one thing I really really loved was the ending. What is the truth? What is truth?

No matter which way I look at it, it’s clear that Verity was a master at manipulating the truth. The only question that remains is: Which truth was she manipulating?

profile.name: Jessica

title: This was so messed up and disturbing, yet I couldn’t put the book down!
body: I’ve read quite a few of Colleen Hoover’s novels and been impressed by how emotionally intense her love stories are. So when I saw she wrote her first suspense thriller, I knew I was in for a quite a ride. The novel follows Lowen Asleigh, a struggling author, who’s in a dire financial state. She’s gotten an eviction notice for her apartment and doesn’t have a new manuscript to sell to publishers, having spend most of her time caring for her terminally ill mother. Then she gets an offer of a lifetime. Bestselling Verity Crawford has gotten badly injured in car accident and her husband, Jeremy Crawford, wants Lowen to finish her popular novel series. Desperate to keep a roof over her head, Lowen accepts. She comes over to the Crawford’s secluded house in Virginia to go through Verity’s notes and outlines for future novels. Instead, she stumbles upon Verity’s unfinished autobiography detailing disturbing thoughts and chilling admissions, including a confession of what really happened the day Verity and Jeremy’s daughter died. Should Lowen show the autobiography to Jeremy, who’s a devoted to his injured wife and oblivious to her true character? Or keep it to herself and not devastate an already grieving father and husband? I honestly didn’t know much more than that going into this novel and I feel like that really is the best way of experiencing it. Go into this blind and the reveals and admissions will horrify you. There were parts that difficult for me to read, that left me feeling sick to my stomach. And yet, I couldn’t stop reading out of morbid curiosity. I needed to know what will happen next. How will it end? And yes, the ending shocked me more than the whole book. It left me second guessing everything I thought knew leading up to it. And yet, it fits so well! My opinions on the characters changed from like to hate and hate to like by the time the novel ended. I won’t say who I liked and disliked for that will spoil it (and I will want readers going into this blind!). But I will say this, there are two points of views in this novel, Lowen’s and Verity’s, and they’re very distinct from each other. The pacing didn’t drag or feel rushed, it felt even, just perfect. Do yourself a favour and don’t read this at night like I did. I really regretted it because I was freaking out and unable to sleep. This story is definitely going to haunt me.
body_html:
I’ve read quite a few of Colleen Hoover’s novels and been impressed by how emotionally intense her love stories are. So when I saw she wrote her first suspense thriller, I knew I was in for a quite a ride.
The novel follows Lowen Asleigh, a struggling author, who’s in a dire financial state. She’s gotten an eviction notice for her apartment and doesn’t have a new manuscript to sell to publishers, having spend most of her time caring for her terminally ill mother. Then she gets an offer of a lifetime. Bestselling Verity Crawford has gotten badly injured in car accident and her husband, Jeremy Crawford, wants Lowen to finish her popular novel series. Desperate to keep a roof over her head, Lowen accepts. She comes over to the Crawford’s secluded house in Virginia to go through Verity’s notes and outlines for future novels. Instead, she stumbles upon Verity’s unfinished autobiography detailing disturbing thoughts and chilling admissions, including a confession of what really happened the day Verity and Jeremy’s daughter died. Should Lowen show the autobiography to Jeremy, who’s a devoted to his injured wife and oblivious to her true character? Or keep it to herself and not devastate an already grieving father and husband?
I honestly didn’t know much more than that going into this novel and I feel like that really is the best way of experiencing it. Go into this blind and the reveals and admissions will horrify you.
There were parts that difficult for me to read, that left me feeling sick to my stomach. And yet, I couldn’t stop reading out of morbid curiosity. I needed to know what will happen next. How will it end? And yes, the ending shocked me more than the whole book. It left me second guessing everything I thought knew leading up to it. And yet, it fits so well!
My opinions on the characters changed from like to hate and hate to like by the time the novel ended. I won’t say who I liked and disliked for that will spoil it (and I will want readers going into this blind!). But I will say this, there are two points of views in this novel, Lowen’s and Verity’s, and they’re very distinct from each other. The pacing didn’t drag or feel rushed, it felt even, just perfect.
Do yourself a favour and don’t read this at night like I did. I really regretted it because I was freaking out and unable to sleep. This story is definitely going to haunt me.

title: Wow!!  I couldn't put this book down.
body: This is my first book by Colleen Hoover and it drew me right in. I haven't read a book this good in quite awhile. Be prepared to be shocked by "Verity", as she will hook you in and keep you reading till the end. I keep asking myself why am I reading this shocking story, but am still going with only the last few pages to go. I shall finish it tonight. I shall be reading more of Colleen's books and will be starting "It Ends with Us" next. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5, is because I was shocked by "Verity"... probably an age thing.

profile.name: Luna

title: Left me horrified but couldn’t put it down!
body: Omg. I’m used to reading the romance novels Colleen usually writes so this was definitely different. Those confessions in the manuscript were bone chilling and had my heart racing with horror every time. These types of things to read or imagine are quite a trigger but the whole idea is to make you hate Verity Crawford and that’s exactly what happens with each chapter. How anyone could do what she “did” to her own child is absolutely anxiety inducing but the possibility at the end that it may have all been just the opposite of the truth gave a bit of relief in a way. Seriously, as a mother of 2, I can’t imagine the unbearable pain of losing one of my babies but to think that a mother could have actually resented them before they were even born is sickening. It’s appalling! But it’s an amazingly written book and sorry for the spoilers, but these comments are full of them so I figured it’s allowed. The amount of SEX is unreal but it helps build Verity’s character so I get it. I’m no prude so I won’t complain about it. It is what it is. And obviously if you don’t like “romance” then don’t read about it. Come on! Anyways, amazingly well written and it made my heart pound at times so I can’t say it wasn’t good. Colleen really pushed the limits here and that’s what amazing writers do!

date.raw: Reviewed in Canada on September 21, 2022
profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Okay, but . . .
body: It fell short of what I was expecting. A couple review blurbs made grand promises of this title being “Riveting and unexpected” or “Prepare for your pulse to race” and even that “The energy and pace in this book are like a fun house at a carnival.” Regrettably (or unfortunately) I found none of these to hold much substance in my reading of the book. I will say I found it to be entertaining but not riveting, and developments in the plot line were not what I would call unexpected. The story premise was a good one and held some promise in the early going, but Hoover continued to “telegraph” where it was going and to large extent how it would end. (The actual ending did deliver a nice twist, but the book needed more than that to score big points from me). There was never a point at which my pulse raced, and while the story pacing was all right (as in a “notch above OK”) the flashes of energy were too infrequent to much matter. (A carnival fun house this was not). I know there will be scores of reviewers who take great umbrage at my comments, overall, but that’s what book reviews represent; one opinion versus others. I will not discourage the reading of this book but neither do I give it a strong recommendation. I can’t find enough to give it 4 stars, but will offer (imo) an honest 3.5

title: 📖R E V I E W📖
body: Verity by @colleenhoover Rating: 🌙🌙🌙🌙🌙/5 Spice: 🌶/5 CHECK TRIGGER WARNINGS! Abortion, child abuse, murder, adultery, etc.  Summary: Lowen Ashleigh is a struggling writer on the brink of financial ruin when she accepts the job offer of a lifetime. Jeremy Crawford, husband of bestselling author Verity Crawford, has hired Lowen to complete the remaining books in a successful series his injured wife is unable to finish. As Lowen arrives at the Crawford home to sort through Verity’s notes, she comes across an unfinished biography Verity never intended anyone to read.  Review: Oh my god. I didn’t expect ANYTHING THAT HAPPENED IN THIS BOOK 🥸 I get the reactions I’ve seen from ppl saying “wtf did I just read?” 🌚 K I went into this book thinking it was gna be a dark romance but this got me messed UP MAN!!! The suspense… the thrill… the twist… omg everything I’ve heard about colleen hoover has been amazing, but this was just shocking and absolutely not what I expected at all. I was just thinking I was going to be reading some contemporary romance. But this my god, it was dark. Disturbing. Chilling. But when I say I couldn’t put the book down, I mean it. I was supposed to be eating lunch and my fiancé asked me why I wasn’t eating and I was like “I just need to finish these last 100 pages” ahahahah omg. What a crazy ride. The ending hit me like a truck??? Made me question everything??? Nonetheless I think it was excellent, Colleen Hoover weaved such a dark and disturbing story of love, loss, and tragedy in this hauntingly suspenseful novel.
body_html:
Verity by @colleenhoover
Rating: 🌙🌙🌙🌙🌙/5
Spice: 🌶/5
CHECK TRIGGER WARNINGS! Abortion, child abuse, murder, adultery, etc.

Summary: Lowen Ashleigh is a struggling writer on the brink of financial ruin when she accepts the job offer of a lifetime. Jeremy Crawford, husband of bestselling author Verity Crawford, has hired Lowen to complete the remaining books in a successful series his injured wife is unable to finish. As Lowen arrives at the Crawford home to sort through Verity’s notes, she comes across an unfinished biography Verity never intended anyone to read.

Review: Oh my god. I didn’t expect ANYTHING THAT HAPPENED IN THIS BOOK 🥸 I get the reactions I’ve seen from ppl saying “wtf did I just read?” 🌚 K I went into this book thinking it was gna be a dark romance but this got me messed UP MAN!!! The suspense… the thrill… the twist… omg everything I’ve heard about colleen hoover has been amazing, but this was just shocking and absolutely not what I expected at all. I was just thinking I was going to be reading some contemporary romance. But this my god, it was dark. Disturbing. Chilling. But when I say I couldn’t put the book down, I mean it. I was supposed to be eating lunch and my fiancé asked me why I wasn’t eating and I was like “I just need to finish these last 100 pages” ahahahah omg. What a crazy ride. The ending hit me like a truck??? Made me question everything??? Nonetheless I think it was excellent, Colleen Hoover weaved such a dark and disturbing story of love, loss, and tragedy in this hauntingly suspenseful novel.

title: UNPOPULAR OPINION
body: ** UNPOPULAR OPINION **  I finished this book in one day. I couldn’t put the book down. I needed to know... the ending... There were some scenes in this book that were so creepy I actually got chills and was kind of freaked out. But the ending was disappointing. If you decide to read it, you may enjoy it like so many others.

title: Sweet ending, kinda dull.
body: This book was okay. It feel flat of expectations for me. Compared to IEWU, it lacked a lot of drama and character development.  It had some drama, but for a CoHo book? It was meh. Dragged on at times and took me a long time to finish because at times I just didn't care or skimmed through internal monologue since it was just reiterating things we already knew. Lily and Atlas get A HEA, despite some hiccups.

profile.name: r

title: Brilliant
body: The book came in excellent condition.  First of all, if you don't remember or didn't read the first book there are a few trigger warnings such as an abusive relationship, alcohol abuse, attempted rape, cancer, childbirth, depression, domestic abuse (graphic), infertility (brief mention but then resolved), pregnancy, suicide (brief discussion) and violence.  In fear that I could not remember something from the first one (It Ends With Us, #Itendwithus). But the book has light ways to bring us memories from past situations. I enjoy the Author writing its simple and easy to flow throughout the book, it was extremely fast passed in my opinion I had to stop reading it to make it last longer, so I could have this feeling of being in this world longer, I love Atlas and Lily, they have a special place in my heart.  Lily is dealing with her emotions putting her mother's duties first, and trying to deal with her ex-husband Ryle. She evolves along the book showing confidence and growth possible with the support of others like her mother and sister in law with whom she keeps a lovely friendship, Not only Lily finds challenges but Atlas's life changes have ways, giving him a purpose to fight harder for what he loves, I will end this review just saying that nothing felt cringe in my opinion, which sometimes this is not the case in situations where real but serious topics can be badly portraited. Both books will be easily reread a few times by me.

Lily is dealing with her emotions putting her mother's duties first, and trying to deal with her ex-husband Ryle. profile.name: Chloe

title: I see why people love this book
body: 4.5 stars. I see why people love this book. I see why people love 𝘈𝘵𝘭𝘢𝘴.  The thing with this book is that I loved the familial narratives more than the romance, probably because we already know how amazing Atlas is—we just get to see more of it. It wasn't like reading the first book where Ryle left me off balance, where I wondered how Atlas would fit into the narrative, and where I worried for Lily. In fact, the latter of those is probably something that could have been amped up a tad to add more tension to the story, but it was fine as is.  Essentially, I knew what to expect from all the characters that appeared in It Ends with Us, so it was actually new additions to the story and how they wove into these characters lives that really brought It Starts with Us to life for me. I love the hard conversations about family and family loyalty. I love the empathy alongside the hard boundaries.  It Starts with Us continues the conversation of generational cycles in families but with an added layer that I won't spoil, and that's what I love this book for more than anything.
body_html:

In fact, the latter of those is probably something that could have been amped up a tad to add more tension to the story, but it was fine as is.

Essentially, I knew what to expect from all the characters that appeared in It Ends with Us, so it was actually new additions to the story and how they wove into these characters lives that really brought It Starts with Us to life for me. I love the hard conversations about family and family loyalty. I love the empathy alongside the hard boundaries.

It Starts with Us continues the conversation of generational cycles in families but with an added layer that I won't spoil, and that's what I love this book for more than anything.

profile.name: RosaV

title: Very Important, But Shortsighted in its Overall Assessment of our Condition
body: This is an important book. It argues that smart phones (and other screens) have resulted in a troubled generation subject to mental illness. Instead of playing (preferably outdoors), children retreat into themselves and their social media, to their great detriment. This is argued at length and it is supported by extensive analysis, data, and first-rate social science research.  It is important that this book was written; there is general acceptance of the overall thesis already, but not the radical call to arms which the book represents, a call to arms from a prominent and trusted scholar.  Having said that, I must take issue with some of the principal points of the book. For example, he argues that helicopter parents are too risk-averse “in the physically safe environments that surround most children in developed nations today” (p. 70). Part of this point turns on his view that those who would sexually abuse or otherwise harm children are now operating on line; they are not prowling the streets of our neighborhoods. I think this is indefensible for a number of reasons. First, we can observe with our own eyes. Individuals are being pushed off of subway platforms onto train rails; whether these individuals are sexual abusers of children or not, they are on the subway platforms. In a number of our major cities we have seen “defund the police” actions, the redefinition of felonies to misdemeanors, cash-free bail, the tolerance of mentally-challenged homeless individuals and omnipresent property crime driven by drug addiction. We also have omnipresent pornography. This may defuse some individuals’ urgings but it might also suggest practices of which the consumer was previously unaware and, hence, awaken interest in those practices.  It is arguable that the “sexual revolution” was won, but that the losers in the struggle were women. They may now curse like sailors and be sexually promiscuous, but that does not necessarily represent a victory. Men now “fail to launch”; millions of able-bodied individuals have no interest in seeking employment; “toxic males” have been demonized; welfare protocols have encouraged single-parent families; marriage and family formation have been postponed; birth rates are down; STD’s are up; the concept of and the importance of the nuclear family are under assault. “Women’s liberation” has often come at the cost of children and abortion is the prominent election issue for one of our major political parties.  JH acknowledges some of these issues in passing, but he does not make them central elements of his etiology of anxiety in the way that he does smart phones. This may be because of his age; he simply takes these things for granted rather than seeing them as conscious public choices. I am a generation older than JH (by 22 years). I remember being in a “smoke shop” in Norwood, Ohio buying candy when the proprietor showed a potential consumer some ‘pornographic’ pictures. My friends and I gawked in astonishment. The pictures (we assumed they had to be French) were of semi-clad individuals tossing beach balls to one another. A mile down the street from the smoke shop was a public swimming pool; one day, sitting in the boys’ locker room, I heard older (probably 15-16 year-olds) discussing the effects of marijuana. I was astounded, since I assumed that marijuana was something that was only consumed by jazz musicians in big cities. Fifty years later I read student papers (in my creative nonfiction class) that discussed designer drugs in greater detail than one might expect in a true crime television series. When I was in college in 1959 I was urged by my prefects and rector to attend a lecture on pornography in South Bend. This was eye-opening (in many respects) since it brought to my consciousness a medley of practices and kinks of which I was totally unaware. I should note that my adolescence had not been “sheltered”; I worked construction from ages 15-16 and saw men fighting with hammers and heard (nearly each week) the exploits of one electrician who spent each weekend on “motel dates”.  China does not have drug dealers; they execute them. I point that out to reinforce the point that societies make conscious choices. One does not put chewing gum under tables in Singapore. When I first visited the United Kingdom in 1973 there was a prominent story in the London papers of vandals spraying graffiti on trains. The young offenders were required to clean the trains and their families were fined 500 pounds, a considerable sum at that time. I am not recommending that we execute drug dealers or order 20 lashes for misdemeanors, but we are currently losing 100,000 individuals (often children) to fentanyl each year, and while we see some hand-wringing we do not see the actions that could be taken to reduce its presence in our society.  In the late 90’s I was interviewed by a local radio station concerning a book I had just published on my adolescence. The interviewer would have been from JH’s generation; his first question was a wistful one about the grand old days when children could freely and safely play outside (something JH now advocates as a central part of his program). I responded that it was wonderful; we had adventures every day in the woods that adjoined the park at the bottom of our street, but I added that he should remember that we were safe in part because we were heavily armed. We had large knives, hatchets and B.B. guns. More important, we knew that if we were confronted by a child abuser we would be able to utilize those weapons with no concern whatsoever that the law would see things from the abuser’s point of view. A corollary: if there was any evidence of such abuse in our neighborhood our fathers might mete out street justice, knowing that the law would be on our side. Now, increasingly, the law favors the criminals over the victims. The point is that the generally safe environments in developed countries of which JH writes are not all that safe and the likelihood of justice for the victim has been reduced over the years as a matter of public policy. A few years ago two drug addicts broke into the home of an elderly couple in our neighborhood. The man shot one (who survived) and killed the other. The universal public response was that ‘he was lucky that he did that in Missouri’. On the other hand, a woman a few streets away was followed home and murdered after a drug addict saw her using an ATM machine. This was in an upper middle class, putatively safe neighborhood.  I love the idea of kids being able to play outside and take some risks and I fully support JH’s advocacy for the replacement of screen time with free play time, but I believe that the etiology of our current condition has resulted, in part, from what is usually termed the “coarsening of our society” and that that coarsening is in large measure the result of conscious changes in public policies and mores that could be altered. That coarsening affects children in particular and one can understand why they might wish to retreat to their bedrooms and enter an artificial world rather than the one that they currently are forced to inhabit.
body_html:
This is an important book. It argues that smart phones (and other screens) have resulted in a troubled generation subject to mental illness. Instead of playing (preferably outdoors), children retreat into themselves and their social media, to their great detriment. This is argued at length and it is supported by extensive analysis, data, and first-rate social science research.

It is important that this book was written; there is general acceptance of the overall thesis already, but not the radical call to arms which the book represents, a call to arms from a prominent and trusted scholar.

Having said that, I must take issue with some of the principal points of the book. For example, he argues that helicopter parents are too risk-averse “in the physically safe environments that surround most children in developed nations today” (p. 70). Part of this point turns on his view that those who would sexually abuse or otherwise harm children are now operating on line; they are not prowling the streets of our neighborhoods. I think this is indefensible for a number of reasons. First, we can observe with our own eyes. Individuals are being pushed off of subway platforms onto train rails; whether these individuals are sexual abusers of children or not, they are on the subway platforms. In a number of our major cities we have seen “defund the police” actions, the redefinition of felonies to misdemeanors, cash-free bail, the tolerance of mentally-challenged homeless individuals and omnipresent property crime driven by drug addiction. We also have omnipresent pornography. This may defuse some individuals’ urgings but it might also suggest practices of which the consumer was previously unaware and, hence, awaken interest in those practices.

It is arguable that the “sexual revolution” was won, but that the losers in the struggle were women. They may now curse like sailors and be sexually promiscuous, but that does not necessarily represent a victory. Men now “fail to launch”; millions of able-bodied individuals have no interest in seeking employment; “toxic males” have been demonized; welfare protocols have encouraged single-parent families; marriage and family formation have been postponed; birth rates are down; STD’s are up; the concept of and the importance of the nuclear family are under assault. “Women’s liberation” has often come at the cost of children and abortion is the prominent election issue for one of our major political parties.

JH acknowledges some of these issues in passing, but he does not make them central elements of his etiology of anxiety in the way that he does smart phones. This may be because of his age; he simply takes these things for granted rather than seeing them as conscious public choices. I am a generation older than JH (by 22 years). I remember being in a “smoke shop” in Norwood, Ohio buying candy when the proprietor showed a potential consumer some ‘pornographic’ pictures. My friends and I gawked in astonishment. The pictures (we assumed they had to be French) were of semi-clad individuals tossing beach balls to one another. A mile down the street from the smoke shop was a public swimming pool; one day, sitting in the boys’ locker room, I heard older (probably 15-16 year-olds) discussing the effects of marijuana. I was astounded, since I assumed that marijuana was something that was only consumed by jazz musicians in big cities. Fifty years later I read student papers (in my creative nonfiction class) that discussed designer drugs in greater detail than one might expect in a true crime television series. When I was in college in 1959 I was urged by my prefects and rector to attend a lecture on pornography in South Bend. This was eye-opening (in many respects) since it brought to my consciousness a medley of practices and kinks of which I was totally unaware. I should note that my adolescence had not been “sheltered”; I worked construction from ages 15-16 and saw men fighting with hammers and heard (nearly each week) the exploits of one electrician who spent each weekend on “motel dates”.

China does not have drug dealers; they execute them. I point that out to reinforce the point that societies make conscious choices. One does not put chewing gum under tables in Singapore. When I first visited the United Kingdom in 1973 there was a prominent story in the London papers of vandals spraying graffiti on trains. The young offenders were required to clean the trains and their families were fined 500 pounds, a considerable sum at that time. I am not recommending that we execute drug dealers or order 20 lashes for misdemeanors, but we are currently losing 100,000 individuals (often children) to fentanyl each year, and while we see some hand-wringing we do not see the actions that could be taken to reduce its presence in our society.

In the late 90’s I was interviewed by a local radio station concerning a book I had just published on my adolescence. The interviewer would have been from JH’s generation; his first question was a wistful one about the grand old days when children could freely and safely play outside (something JH now advocates as a central part of his program). I responded that it was wonderful; we had adventures every day in the woods that adjoined the park at the bottom of our street, but I added that he should remember that we were safe in part because we were heavily armed. We had large knives, hatchets and B.B. guns. More important, we knew that if we were confronted by a child abuser we would be able to utilize those weapons with no concern whatsoever that the law would see things from the abuser’s point of view. A corollary: if there was any evidence of such abuse in our neighborhood our fathers might mete out street justice, knowing that the law would be on our side. Now, increasingly, the law favors the criminals over the victims. The point is that the generally safe environments in developed countries of which JH writes are not all that safe and the likelihood of justice for the victim has been reduced over the years as a matter of public policy. A few years ago two drug addicts broke into the home of an elderly couple in our neighborhood. The man shot one (who survived) and killed the other. The universal public response was that ‘he was lucky that he did that in Missouri’. On the other hand, a woman a few streets away was followed home and murdered after a drug addict saw her using an ATM machine. This was in an upper middle class, putatively safe neighborhood.

I love the idea of kids being able to play outside and take some risks and I fully support JH’s advocacy for the replacement of screen time with free play time, but I believe that the etiology of our current condition has resulted, in part, from what is usually termed the “coarsening of our society” and that that coarsening is in large measure the result of conscious changes in public policies and mores that could be altered. That coarsening affects children in particular and one can understand why they might wish to retreat to their bedrooms and enter an artificial world rather than the one that they currently are forced to inhabit.

profile.name: Richard B.  Schwartz

title: Jonathan Haidt's The Anxious Generation Sparks Urgent Reflection and Action
body: Jonathan Haidt's The Anxious Generation is, simply put, one of the most important and vital works of nonfiction I've read, and—quite possibly—the most influential book on my wife and I's parenting style and approach to technology.  The Anxious Generation is bombshell after bombshell detonating all of our preconceived assumptions about social media, Gen Z, parenting, "safetyism," mobile phones, childhood, education, and mental health. You've probably long suspected some of Haidt's observations and conclusions, but to see them put to words—and backed by heaps and heaps of research, neuroscience, philosophy, and spiritual musings—is to have your assumptions about what we consider "normal" rocked to its very core.  I'm so thankful I read this book prior to the birth of my daughter. This is a book I want to put into the hands of every parent, want-to-be parent, teacher, politician, tech CEO, or anyone who works/engages with children and/or cares about the collective mental health of our country. I firmly believe that if enough people—especially parents of young children—read this book, it could change the trajectory of our nation's approach to technology and childhood.  In short, Haidt's argument boils down to one salient point: We've overprotected our children from the real world, and underprotected them from the virtual world.. He advocates for a return to the "play-based childhood," and points the transition to the "phone-based childhood" as the primary driver of a significant increase in anxiety, depression, and self-harm among teenagers—especially teenage girls. Additionally, because of culture's perpetual fear-based approach to child-rearing, we've left our kids woefully unprepared for the pressures of the "real world"—and points to evidence of the startling number of Gen Zers and younger Millennials who appears trapped in a state of perpetual young adulthood.  The best aspect of The Anxious Generation is how easy it would've been for Haidt to just document a series of social ills and offer a diagnosis. But the back half of this book is full of extremely practical steps, application points, and "rules" for ensuring your children don't have their neurobiology hacked by tech companies who only want to monopolize their attention—mental health consequences be damned. And, even though the harms hone in on Gen Z and younger Millennials, I find myself often convicted of my own habitual phone use throughout the course of this book and I realize even I didn't escape unscathed.  Read this book. Buy a hard copy and highlight it. I want to give a copy to all of my friends, young parents, and teachers. And not just because I want to discuss this book—but, because as Haidt points out over and over again, this is a cultural issue that requires mass collective action in order to change. So, the more people who read this book and are startled awake by its findings, then the easier it'll be to implement the changes Haidt recommends.

profile.name: Joe Terrell

title: Timely and Wonderfully Researched
body: This is an excellent read for parent book clubs. Everything we already “knew” about the effects of social media and phone addiction have been confirmed with data that Haida shows us. I cannot recommend this book to enough people. As a millennial parent, I am going to be utilizing the advice Haidt offers on when to introduce smart phones and social media to my children. My kids mental health is far more important to me than keeping up with the Jones’ on giving kids phones too early. Praise for the book. Please read!

profile.name: Haley

title: Save the kids from the curse of smartphones
body: Something is ailing in the generation who lived through adolescence in the second decade of the twenty-first century. Jonathan Haidt produces a series of graphs to show that they are suffering from a sudden and dramatic increase in levels of anxiety and depression. Two big questions arise from this. One is why? The other is what can be done about it? Haidt’s answer to the first question is that smartphones and social media are to blame. The sudden and dramatic rise in the incidence of mental illness among the young, occurred between 2010 and 2015 immediately following the introduction of smartphones. Correlation, of course, is not the same as causation and there might have been other things in play, international and economic crises for instance. Haidt, however, presents a convincing argument that smartphones and social media are the real culprits and explains how they have, effectively, hijacked the normal development of childhood and adolescence with serious consequences for mental health. Haidt summarises his answer to the second question in four points. No smartphones before high school, no social media before the age of 16, no phones in schools and, finally, more unsupervised play and childhood independence. Although the book has lots of data and graphs, it is written in plain English and structured in a way to make the point easy to follow for the non-specialist reader. Each chapter ends with a summary of the main points covered. And while it is criticising the harm that new technology can do, it also demonstrates the real benefits of technology through an accompanying website in which Haidt and his collaborators are constantly updating and engaging in further discussions on the topic. For example, it contains a collaborative review of all the arguments that something other than smartphones are behind the epidemic of mental illness.

profile.name: David Hastings

title: Essential Reading for Everyone Who Cares for Children
body: A global epidemic of mental illness and maladaptive behaviors has emerged among our youth over the past decade. This has affected such a high proportion of the next generation that it threatens the future of healthy societies. This book lays out its foundation as a combination of overprotected children and the advent of the smart phone with unlimited apps designed to capture and maintain children’s attention for endless hours. Importantly, it not only presents evidence of the critical role of these two major factors, but also provides well documented and inexpensive solutions to improve the mental health and social development of children at every stage of their life. It is written to be easily understood by the average reader but at the same time provides extensive references with links to continuously updated web sites for leaders in health, education and government who want to change their institutions and pursue these topics in more depth.

title: I’m so grateful that someone finally articulated this message!
body: I have never written any product review before, but have been shouting out about this book from the moment I began reading. I love that it goes beyond despair and handwringing about the problem, and delivers reasonable and actionable steps for change. As a teacher and a parent, I have felt this book’s message in my gut, and I am so grateful someone took the time and effort to research, articulate, and deliver this message to (hopefully) an enormous audience. I cannot praise The Anxious Generation enough!

profile.name: Jill D Harder

title: Serious Questions and Difficult Solutions
body: Social scientist Jonathan Haidt’s The Anxious Generation articulates details of a new psychological/social malady swiftly metastasizing in our culture. Wickedly, it begins in childhood, with the consent and abetting of adults. Smartphones, and other digital devices, “bring so many interesting experiences to children and adolescents that they cause a serious problem. They reduce interest in all non-screen-based forms of experience (author’s italics)”. This is the fundamental understanding at the core of the author’s thesis. Throughout The Anxious Generation, Haidt attempts to ask and answer in detail the following questions of the toxic cultural change we are living through: What has happened? How do we know it has happened? Why has it happened? What can we do about it?  Haidt writes: “I’ll show what governments, tech companies, schools and parents can do to reverse the disastrous transition from play-based to phone-based childhood.” He gives us a banquet of food for thought, but the elephant in the room remains: are citizens hungry for what he serves?  The book asserts that childhood’s necessary learning experiences have been curtailed by a cultural confluence of toxic events: safetyism that has moved from exclusive emphasis on physical safety to include now fears regarding emotional safety (safe rooms in colleges). Documented diminished confidence in faith-based and civil institutions also contributes to more disassociated adult human interaction.  “On the internet, everyone is the same age, which is no particular age. This the main reason why a phone-based adolescence is badly mismatched with the needs of adolescents…It all got worse during the COVID years of ‘social distancing’ and online everything.” According to studies reported by Haidt, “45% of teens report that they use the internet ‘almost constantly’…[This] has enormous implications for cognition.”  In 2017, Israeli psychologist, Professor Sam Vaknin, characterized the hording or paucity of hits on social media “like” buttons as a conditioning process, comparing it to the electrodes implanted in a rat’s brain to deliver a pleasure-jolt of dopamine. This conditions the rat to choose the pleasure bar instead of the food bar, and the rat will begin to starve itself. Vaknin, citing eating disorders and suicide statistics among teenagers, especially girls, stated that giving up addiction to social media is a two-step process that requires first, deprograming, and second, withdrawal. What has evolved is, en-masse, a serious mental condition, in kind with brainwashing.  Haidt offers potential solutions to the early, deleterious pre-teen exposure to smartphone dysphoria: 1. No smartphones before high school. 2.No social media before 16. 3. Phone-free schools. 4. Far more unsupervised play and childhood independence. The Anxious Generation says these goals probably might be effective. But will enough parents collectively agree to them? There is no current answer to that question.  Haidt writes: “The Great Rewiring of Childhood pulled young people out of real-world communities, including their own families, and created a new kind of childhood lived in multiple, rapidly shifting networks. One inevitable result was anomie, or normlessness, because stable and binding moralities cannot form when everything is in flux…The phone-based life produces spiritual degradation, not just in adolescents, but in all of us…In 2010 there was little sign of a mental health crisis. Now it’s all around us.”  --Tom Casey

Social scientist Jonathan Haidt’s The Anxious Generation articulates details of a new psychological/social malady swiftly metastasizing in our culture. Wickedly, it begins in childhood, with the consent and abetting of adults. Smartphones, and other digital devices, “bring so many interesting experiences to children and adolescents that they cause a serious problem. They reduce interest in all non-screen-based forms of experience (author’s italics)”. This is the fundamental understanding at the core of the author’s thesis. Throughout The Anxious Generation, Haidt attempts to ask and answer in detail the following questions of the toxic cultural change we are living through: What has happened? How do we know it has happened? Why has it happened? What can we do about it?

Haidt writes: “I’ll show what governments, tech companies, schools and parents can do to reverse the disastrous transition from play-based to phone-based childhood.” He gives us a banquet of food for thought, but the elephant in the room remains: are citizens hungry for what he serves?

The book asserts that childhood’s necessary learning experiences have been curtailed by a cultural confluence of toxic events: safetyism that has moved from exclusive emphasis on physical safety to include now fears regarding emotional safety (safe rooms in colleges). Documented diminished confidence in faith-based and civil institutions also contributes to more disassociated adult human interaction.

“On the internet, everyone is the same age, which is no particular age. This the main reason why a phone-based adolescence is badly mismatched with the needs of adolescents…It all got worse during the COVID years of ‘social distancing’ and online everything.” According to studies reported by Haidt, “45% of teens report that they use the internet ‘almost constantly’…[This] has enormous implications for cognition.”

In 2017, Israeli psychologist, Professor Sam Vaknin, characterized the hording or paucity of hits on social media “like” buttons as a conditioning process, comparing it to the electrodes implanted in a rat’s brain to deliver a pleasure-jolt of dopamine. This conditions the rat to choose the pleasure bar instead of the food bar, and the rat will begin to starve itself. What has evolved is, en-masse, a serious mental condition, in kind with brainwashing.

Haidt offers potential solutions to the early, deleterious pre-teen exposure to smartphone dysphoria: 1. No smartphones before high school. 2.No social media before 16. 3. Phone-free schools. 4. Far more unsupervised play and childhood independence. The Anxious Generation says these goals probably might be effective. But will enough parents collectively agree to them? There is no current answer to that question.

Haidt writes: “The Great Rewiring of Childhood pulled young people out of real-world communities, including their own families, and created a new kind of childhood lived in multiple, rapidly shifting networks. One inevitable result was anomie, or normlessness, because stable and binding moralities cannot form when everything is in flux…The phone-based life produces spiritual degradation, not just in adolescents, but in all of us…In 2010 there was little sign of a mental health crisis. Now it’s all around us.”

--Tom Casey

profile.name: T. P. Casey

title: Powerful Call to Action to Protect Our Children from the Real Threats
body: Documentaries such as The Social Dilemma and The Creepy Line showed people how they were being manipulated, brainwashed, and mentally impaired online. For years, books like Last Child in the Woods, showed us the negative effects of never leaving our house. During the pandemic, unscientific mandates of never leaving your home, and being glued to your devices, left people mentally and physically impaired.  And yet people still don't get it. Millions of children (the focus of this book) and adults are suffering from the rewiring of their brains. Mental illness, anxiety, suicide. And it sets up their future for failure as well. As Nehls describes in his equally important book, The Indoctrinated Brain, we've now become easily controlled and influenced to believe anything.  The Anxious Generation is likely the most important book on this subject to date. If you are a parent who thought phones and devices were just harmless "computer stuff," read this book. If you think your child needs a smartphone, read this book. If you think your kids should be on social media before they are an adult, you really need to read this book.  We've allowed an avenue for our children to be influenced, indoctrinated, and led into dangerous paths of failing mental and physical well-being. While the author sometimes relies too much on the failed theory of evolution (See Darwin's House of Cards, Taking Leave of Darwin, or Axe's Undeniable), his message here is imperative. We've become so worried about our children outside of our home, we have completely failed to protect them on-line. Now whole generations are suffering.  Parents need to parent again and protect their children from the real threats.

profile.name: WisdomQuest

title: More for Haidt to Do
body: More for Haidt to Do  Here’s how he seems to work: A problem/issue catches Jonathon Haidt’s attention, he studies it, gets more and more of it in his head, tries to do something else; gives in, and then produces a detailed and objective account of the problem and its solution. He says he didn’t want to write this book but had to; and we are the beneficiaries.  We are lucky the Haidts had children, the children and their friends faced “phone-based childhood” challenges, and the Haidts as responsible/caring parents struggled with solutions. Having found “working solutions” and shared them, we as readers/society have starting points to cope with a beneficial technology that greatly exceeded our readiness for it.  Hopeful anticipation: Prof. Haidt is too young to be concerned about the impact of IT on seniors dealing with end of life issues: Endless on-line scams, curtained access to financial and medical information due to excessive privacy filters, and gatherings where attention to phones exceeds attention to faces. Hopefully “aging with IT” issues will get his attention soon and move him into his proven process for finding solutions.
body_html:
More for Haidt to Do

Here’s how he seems to work: A problem/issue catches Jonathon Haidt’s attention, he studies it, gets more and more of it in his head, tries to do something else; gives in, and then produces a detailed and objective account of the problem and its solution. He says he didn’t want to write this book but had to; and we are the beneficiaries.

We are lucky the Haidts had children, the children and their friends faced “phone-based childhood” challenges, and the Haidts as responsible/caring parents struggled with solutions. Having found “working solutions” and shared them, we as readers/society have starting points to cope with a beneficial technology that greatly exceeded our readiness for it.

Hopeful anticipation: Prof. Haidt is too young to be concerned about the impact of IT on seniors dealing with end of life issues: Endless on-line scams, curtained access to financial and medical information due to excessive privacy filters, and gatherings where attention to phones exceeds attention to faces. Hopefully “aging with IT” issues will get his attention soon and move him into his proven process for finding solutions.

title: Concise Advice to Protect Your Children from Toxic Social Media
body: As a grandparent watching our grandkids grow up with iPads and smart phones, and the constant conflict this causes with their parents, this book offers a concise set of rules to establish BEFORE you kids become addicted to social media. The author details, through extensive research, all the harm social media can do to young children and teenagers as they grow and develop. The author offers simple, enforceable rules to help parents prevent social media from taking over a child's life and making your life a constant battle to protect them. Highly recommended and a current best seller for a good reason. Buy it.
body_html:
As a grandparent watching our grandkids grow up with iPads and smart phones, and the constant conflict this causes with their parents, this book offers a concise set of rules to establish BEFORE you kids become addicted to
social media. The author details, through extensive research, all the harm social media can do to young children and teenagers as they grow and develop.
The author offers simple, enforceable rules to help parents prevent social media from taking over a child's life and making your life a constant battle to protect them. Highly recommended and a current best seller for a good reason. Buy it.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2024
profile.name: John Farnam

title: A must read for parents especially
body: I read and watched a lot of interviews with the author and felt I understood the message well and agreed with it, didn’t think I needed to read the book to accept the 4 “foundations for healthier childhood” but I am so glad I read it!! Raising children is a complex job and accepting the messaging of reducing social media will only help a little, understanding the complex issue of how and why social media is harmful will probably help us feel better prepared to handle the difficulties that will inevitably come in trying to reduce the screen time and social media exposure to kids and work through their resistance.

profile.name: Lynne S. Irwin

title: Good luck
body: This is a fantastic book, but the problem is that parents who are already aware of the damage screen devices are causing will read this book, but the parents who allow their children unlimited screen time will ignore this book because they see it as judging them. People are set in their ways. The majority of parents and public schools have been successfully duped by big tech, and it will probably be a very slow transition back to the way kids should be raised: with the freedom to be a kid. It's very possible that we won't ever get back to the ways of healthy childhoods, and we'll have zombie adults running the country.

profile.name: Joopadoop

title: Must read for parents!
body: This book inspired me to make changes in my life and my relationship with my phone, but the book is more directed at parents in the active parenting years. (My kids are grown adults now, but I still found it a valuable read). I suggest this book as required reading for any parent with a kid under the age of 18 and specifically new parents. Most parents (and teachers) know that things have gone awry with phones in kids' hands all the time instead of interacting with peers, parents, and anyone around them, and the author showed how things took a turn for the worse when smart phones and social media took over our kid's attention, and their play-based life diminished.  Haidt discusses two trends happening right now: overprotection in the real world and under-protection in the virtual world, which is leading to an anxious generation of those born after 1995. Girls are particularly experiencing more mental health problems of anxiety, depression, and self-harm, and social media is largely to blame. He also discusses boys, but I have girls and so read that part more closely.  The author suggests four foundational reforms:  1. No smart phones before high school 2. No social media before 16 3. Phone-free schools 4. Far more unsupervised play and childhood independence  The bottom line is that kids need to get off their devices and regain control of their minds. As a parent, we can start to make corrections and help our kids be less anxious and curb addiction. The material is well-researched and presented and deserves serious attention.
body_html:
This book inspired me to make changes in my life and my relationship with my phone, but the book is more directed at parents in the active parenting years. (My kids are grown adults now, but I still found it a valuable read).
I suggest this book as required reading for any parent with a kid under the age of 18 and specifically new parents. Most parents (and teachers) know that things have gone awry with phones in kids' hands all the time instead of interacting with peers, parents, and anyone around them, and the author showed how things took a turn for the worse when smart phones and social media took over our kid's attention, and their play-based life diminished.

Haidt discusses two trends happening right now: overprotection in the real world and under-protection in the virtual world, which is leading to an anxious generation of those born after 1995. Girls are particularly experiencing  more mental health problems of anxiety, depression, and self-harm, and social media is largely to blame. He also discusses boys, but I have girls and so read that part more closely. 

The author suggests four foundational reforms:

1. No smart phones before high school
2. No social media before 16
3. Phone-free schools
4. Far more unsupervised play and childhood independence

The bottom line is that kids need to get off their devices and regain control of their minds. 
As a parent, we can start to make corrections and help our kids be less anxious and curb addiction. The material is well-researched and presented and deserves serious attention.

title: Love his work!
body: One of my biggest regrets was giving my children smartphones. Hindsight tells me a lot about how access influenced their attitudes and behaviors. Prior to smartphones, my children were kind and well-mannered. I should have had restrictions at least stead of unlimited data and 24/7 access. I just didn’t know how destructive it was going to be to our family. I’ve loved this authors work for years. I but all his books and watch as many YouTube videos as well. Great stuff! It’s too late for my children, but maybe this will help the next generation.

profile.name: Ben T.

title: Another home run! Sans evolution
body: The media could not be loaded. I absolutely love Jonathan Haidt and pre-ordered this book because I couldn't wait to read and devour like I did the Coddling.  The research is spot on, the message is critically important (though I would say, I don't know that this message is limited to teens. I think Cal Newport's Digital Minimalism book is in order for adults too. The 24 hr news cycle is making us anxious too!) I digress. I love what he has to say about raising children and I have implemented a lot of these ideas with my four children already (disclaimer: Safety Minimalism gets the cops called on you for just letting your children play outside - at least near the suburbs of NYC where I live - but the confidence is a worthy trade off).  The only problem is evolution can't support these claims or sustain them. Evolution is a western-centric limited worldview that can only be described as a process of chaos and chance that has no particular purpose or meaning guiding it. In one of the photos of my review I addressed this when Haidt refers to hunter-gatherers to explain how important play is. The issue is that if evolution is "guiding" us, we can just evolve and adjust again to respond to the deathly threat of the digital revolution. There is no objective, absolute standard that says we must go back to our primitive ways, in fact- for whatever reason "evolution" got rid of play-based childhood and going back could be considered retrograde. Unless people were made with some purpose and design, we have no reason to go on this mission to save childhood. It will be selected out just like all other traits (how do we assume in evolution which traits are the good and which are the bad btw?). Evolution is a worldview that brings about change through death. We can't put all the digital issues of the age back in the box unless we are bold enough to claim that there is an objective standard of truth and morality.  Chapter 8 offers a view that some level of spirituality can "save us." I agree in a sense, but it can't be empty and made up or promulgated as an opiate of the people. God is not to be taken so lightly as our bandaid cure. We can have all of the excellent ideas of this book, without using the made up excuse that we are just mechanical processes to suppress the truth that we were created and designed by God to be saved from our sins only through Jesus' payment for them in his death and the promise of His resurrection. Lots of the world believes this, which is why I say evolution is very western hegemonic and atheistic in its nature to give us a good excuse to getting out of accountability from God.  All that said, I still really love this book and think it is very urgent and should be extended to all adults. But if we really are an unguided, mechanistic bunch of atoms bumping into one another, it really doesn't matter at all that the kids are not alright. They'll adjust. They'll "evolve." God help us.

profile.name: Lois

title: The Most Societally Important Book of the Year
body: Jon Haidt is a brilliant NYU Stern social psychologist who is relentless in his scientific pursuit of the truth. The "Anxious Generation" is a must-read for every parent, educator, administrator and politician, because it documents the enormous and quantifiable "negative externalities" spawned by social media usage. The trends documented are especially deleterious for teenage girls. Haidt marshals evidence of depression, anxiety, self-harm and even suicide and concludes: "Social media use does not just correlate with mental illness; it causes it."  An apt analogy to smoking is drawn, given social media apps are - by design - addicting and marketed to minors. Modern societal norms don't allow pre-teens to buy tobacco, alcohol or enter casinos so why are we allowing them access to "digital fentanyl"? Unfortunately, in a world of "move fast and break things" techno-optimism, what has been broken is teenage mental health. Haidt correctly assesses that this is a collective action problem and offers four foundation recommendations:  1) More unsupervised play and childhood independence; 2) No smartphones before high school; 3) No social media before 16; 4) Phone free schools;  Regulatory frameworks and societal norms often lag Silicon Valley's bleeding-edge speed of development, but the damage being wrought here - and painstakingly documented by Haidt - is becoming visible enough that this book could catalyze real, positive and lasting change. Gift a copy to anyone with younger children or local educators - spread the word and help solve the collective action problem.  Final note: All of Haidt's books are highly recommended, it is just an unfortunate reflection on our current state of affairs that the arc of his publishing gamut runs chronologically from Happiness to Anxiety instead of the reverse order.
body_html:
Jon Haidt is a brilliant NYU Stern social psychologist who is relentless in his scientific pursuit of the truth. The "Anxious Generation" is a must-read for every parent, educator, administrator and politician, because it documents the enormous and quantifiable "negative externalities" spawned by social media usage. The trends documented are especially deleterious for teenage girls. Haidt marshals evidence of depression, anxiety, self-harm and even suicide and concludes: "Social media use does not just correlate with mental illness; it causes it."

An apt analogy to smoking is drawn, given social media apps are - by design - addicting and marketed to minors. Modern societal norms don't allow pre-teens to buy tobacco, alcohol or enter casinos so why are we allowing them access to "digital fentanyl"? Unfortunately, in a world of "move fast and break things" techno-optimism, what has been broken is teenage mental health. Haidt correctly assesses that this is a collective action problem and offers four foundation recommendations:

1) More unsupervised play and childhood independence;
2) No smartphones before high school;
3) No social media before 16;
4) Phone free schools;

Regulatory frameworks and societal norms often lag Silicon Valley's bleeding-edge speed of development, but the damage being wrought here - and painstakingly documented by Haidt - is becoming visible enough that this book could catalyze real, positive and lasting change. Gift a copy to anyone with younger children or local educators - spread the word and help solve the collective action problem.

Final note: All of Haidt's books are highly recommended, it is just an unfortunate reflection on our current state of affairs that the arc of his publishing gamut runs chronologically from Happiness to Anxiety instead of the reverse order.

profile.name: VanStan

title: Social media negatively impacts the mental health and wellness of our children
body: Social media negatively impacts the mental health and wellness of our children. I am a public health professional with a doctorate in epidemiology. I know there is debate on the strength of causal evidence linking social media and youth mental illness. However, Haidt makes the strong case that we have sufficient evidence to act now to reduce exposures. These interventions should then be studied rigorously (eg, clustered randomized controlled trials) to assess their impacts, and contribute to the causal evidence. Even his detractors agree we should reduce exposures to social media.  Unfortunately, we have research evidence asymmetry because the tech companies conduct tons of research on how to increase our use of social media, but we do not have access to their research to assess the harms of their interventions. I agree with Haidt that we should act now *and* conduct more research.  The harms of social media to youth include 1. Sleep deprivation 2. Social deprivation 3. Attention fragmentation 4. Problem use (or addiction)  These are intermediate mechanisms that impact mental health and well-being.
body_html:
Social media negatively impacts the mental health and wellness of our children. I am a public health professional with a doctorate in epidemiology. I know there is debate on the strength of causal evidence linking social media and youth mental illness. However, Haidt makes the strong case that we have sufficient evidence to act now to reduce exposures. These interventions should then be studied rigorously (eg, clustered randomized controlled trials) to assess their impacts, and contribute to the causal evidence. Even his detractors agree we should reduce exposures to social media.

Unfortunately, we have research evidence asymmetry because the tech companies conduct tons of research on how to increase our use of social media, but we do not have access to their research to assess the harms of their interventions. I agree with Haidt that we should act now *and* conduct more research.

The harms of social media to youth include
1. Sleep deprivation
2. Social deprivation
3. Attention fragmentation
4. Problem use (or addiction)

These are intermediate mechanisms that impact mental health and well-being.

profile.name: wilke

title: Early Childhood Educator Review
body: It has been stressed that every parent, grandparent, educator and anyone who works with or cares about children should read this book (The Anxious Generation: How the Great Rewiring of Childhood Is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness) released this week.  As an early childhood educator in this important work of human development with the youngest of students for over 20 years, I have observed an increase of anxiety in the children we serve within the last decade and *definitely* within the last 4 years. It has been concerning, especially since the children I serve are just experiencing their first encounters with the world as they begin to make sense of the world within and around them. My colleagues who teach older ages have described an increase as well so it is obviously not an isolated observation.  When I read the urging a few days ago to read this book from a respected leader in the pedagogy I follow to read, I reviewed the information on it. Since then, I have seen multiple places/people saying this is being heralded as “the most important book” for parents to read. My copy arrived yesterday. I look forward to diving in, and expanding my knowledge and skills to serve families.  I will return to review once I have read it. Based upon the information I know so far, I will rate this 5 stars.

profile.name: Ryan Pollacci

title: convincing, a little dull, not a lot of plausible solutions
body: I thought the book made a convincing case, but Haidt was preaching to the choir when it came to this reader, since I'm one of the few remaining middle-class American adults under 60 who doesn't use a cell phone at all.  The style was a little dull and plodding.  He tries to give some suggestions for fixing the problem, but most of them seem entirely implausible, since most people are so incredibly addicted to their phones. The one that seemed the most workable to me was to make schools phone-free zones, but AFAICT the number of schools doing this is actually going down, partly because parents want to be able to spy on and nag their kids.

title: Excellent information!
body: Jonathan Haidt has written an informative and eye-opening book on the impact of social media and lack of free play on children and teens. The information is frightening, yet Haidt does not leave us without hope. He offers practical and doable solutions that can be successful in recapturing the power of childhood. It will require courage and community. It is my hope we begin-together. I highly recommend this book to parents, grandparents, educators, and everyone who cares about future generations.

profile.name: Christa Soller

title: An Indispensable Resource!
body: "The New Menopause: Navigating Your Path Through Hormonal Change with Purpose, Power" is an insightful and empowering guidebook that sheds light on a topic often shrouded in mystery and misunderstanding. The author's comprehensive approach to navigating menopause is both informative and eye-opening, providing readers with valuable insights into the physical, emotional, and psychological aspects of this natural transition. Through a combination of research-backed information and personal anecdotes, the book offers practical advice and strategies for managing symptoms, embracing change, and reclaiming control over one's health and well-being. What sets this book apart is its emphasis on empowerment and purpose, encouraging women to approach menopause as a time of growth, transformation, and renewed vitality. Overall, "The New Menopause" is an indispensable resource for women seeking to navigate this stage of life with confidence, purpose, and power.

profile.name: Jackie Carlisle

title: Amazing, incredible information.
body: I am in awe of this book and the information you provided. I also listened to the podcast you were recently on as well. I am so obsessed with learning about menopause after my personal journey and listening to yours and those of others. I am reading everything I can get my hands on (journals, books, articles, websites, etc) including the homeopathic side of things, just so that I have clarity with all of the information that is out there. I have been on MHT for about 3 years now and am still working with my gyn to figure out dosing. Like menopause as a whole, everytime you think you figured something out, you haven't completely. I am trying to find a way to further my studies and somehow become more involved in women's health. An athletic trainer for over 30 years, I am not sure I have the capacity to go to nursing school at this point in my life, but want to help others in their journey, somehow and I will find a way to make that happen. Thank you so much....I pre-ordered your book and the wait was so worth it. I am planning on telling my gyn about it!

profile.name: Cathy Walters

title: Lots of good information in one spot
body: I found this book to be extremely informative and interesting. As a woman who is in perimenopause and just starting MHT, I appreciate all of the information about MHT, especially since so many doctors are unaware of the most recent guidelines and are reluctant to prescribe it. I also like that non-pharmacological options are discussed. My biggest complaint is that when other pages of the book are referenced (for example, “See page 145 for a discussion on fiber supplements.”) the page numbers are wrong. When you find the page referenced, there is no mention of the information you are looking for (see photos.) Hopefully this can be addressed in an upcoming reprint. Otherwise, it’s a great book and I’m glad to have read it!
