profile.name: Kidconnexn

title: One Chapter needs a little more information
body: Dr. Mary Claire has really helped me understand my perimenopause symptoms and helped me to be an advocate for myself. One chapter needs a little more information on it is the recommendation on getting a calcium score test done. Patients need to know that Calcium test or CAC isn't a desirable test because it doesn't show soft plaque. Soft plaque is what causes stenosis of the coronary arteries and is only seen on a CTA. If I have high cholesterol and high LDLs and go and get a CAC, test, and it comes back zero that doesn't mean I am not a risk for coronary artery disease. For example, if I go on Lipitor, a statin drug, and my calcium score is zero and I go back and get a CAC in a couple of months of being on Lipitor, your calcium score of zero will go up! My doctor told me that statin drugs are raising people's CAC scores! When his patients see this they can't understand why this is happening. Statin drugs harden the soft plaque. Soft plaque, the plaque that is more thrombogenic, is hardened from statin drugs and now is calcified plaque. Thus, bringing up your calcium score. I highly recommend a CTA and not a CAC. CTA will show soft plaque and where it is. The location of the soft plaque, too is very important. My own mom had a very high CAC score because she was on Lipitor for years. Research has proven this with a large analysis of the MESA dataset that demonstrated that statins are associated with increasing CAC score.

profile.name: Sheri Y.

title: Nine years of “mystery” symptoms and it was all hormones
body: This is THE quintessential reference guide for all women as they age into their mid-thirties and beyond. Dr. Haver covers the expected but also the many non-traditional symptoms of menopause, which I endured for NINE YEARS. I saw a multitude of specialists with no solutions. From asthma to frozen shoulder to tinnitus, it’s all here. My toughest symptom was debilitating joint pain. So much so I thought I had rheumatoid arthritis. Turns out it was estrogen deficiency, so I have given HRT another shot. Life changing! She talks a great deal about HRT but also emphasizes lifestyle changes critical to successfully treating the multitude of woes associated with this massive chapter of transition. Well referenced, with simple strategies that are immediately actionable and empowering, The New Menopause delivers a powerful message around the need for better education and advocacy around women’s healthcare.

title: Groundbreaking and brave
body: I'm only 1/3 of the way through the book, but I was an early MHT patient (thank you California, 2013!) and this is the information I have been defending, recommending, praising, advocating for since life-changing intervention 12 + years ago. My horrible symptoms abated, and I wasn't ever really aware then of the long term benefits including cardiovascular, osteo, cognitive, etc. until Dr. Haver and her peers have lately gained notoriety and attention to this. I have to commend the bravery this author demonstrates in utilizing language. These are not friendly times and this incredibly dense medical information presented factually but also with an acknowledgment to the patriarchal history of medicine, racism, sexism, etc. PHEW! and Texas! Thank you, I'm really feeling validated and vindicated for my choices.

title: Skip the manifesto and buy this book instead
body: I read the "other" big menopause book last year, and The New Menopause blows it out of the water. It's less academic, less angry feminist (that's coming from a feminist!), easier to digest and more actionable than the manifesto. I had an HRT appointment already scheduled three days after I received it, and I was way more prepared for it using Dr. Haver's guidance. I've also always been big on using nutrition, supplements, and exercise to support my health and it's great to read guidance on those things as well. I'm telling ALL my girlfriends about it!

title: This ain’t pretty, but reality seldom is
body: Major Hegseth has put into words the uncomfortable reality of how our military warfighters are being taken out of action, by anti-American insurgents in the White House, and their carefully selected minions-aka-senior “leaders” within the pentagon. As a retired warfighter I can attest to the truths he exposes-about the deliberate dismantling of all that once assured each American that they were protected from threats not just outside our borders, but the insidious threats that have been grown and deliberately placed in all the areas we once deem sacred. Hegseth writes in such a way, that no one reading his book can walk away from it and ask-“why didn’t anyone warn us”. This is a must read for every American concerned about the direction our country is going. Why? Because unless you have a strong, well disciplined, patriotic military protecting your home-you’ll have no homeland to protect. Every standard that once ensured the fitness of military recruits to serve-physical, mental, psychological, chemical(as in not having a hx of illegal drug use), criminal, moral has either been eliminated, greatly reduced, or at the very list been something that can be waived-in order to put them in uniform. Leaders trying to maintain order and discipline with the ranks of those they lead, honor the oath they have sworn to are punished by their own leaders-as happened to Major Hegseth. So if you really want to know the key factors that are destroying our military, and oh by the way your security as an American-Hegseth’s book should be read and digested.

profile.name: Rosiet

title: Pete Is Spot On.......
body: Received this book yesterday and we read it straight through last night. Pete is spot on....we know because we lived it and could not speak about it. Our boys chose not to serve because they saw what we endured during the Vietnam years. And I am personally familiar with assigning women in areas that only cause heartache when another male member of my team comes back from TDY and tried to explain to his wife how his fellow female member of the team is now pregnant because of his close quarters and a vulnerable weakness. And how numerous times I had to send 2 airmen instead of 1 to do a job because the female team member could not physically carry the equipment. Also how male airmen had to do extra TDYs because their female team members had problems at home with children or were pregnant. Morale was very low when I retired and my wife was happy that I no longer had continual unrelated combat stress. Now with the woke indoctrination, I am not recommending that our grandsons serve today. Thank you Pete for your warning.....I pray it is not too late.  Dr. Patrick J. Oster, USAF Retired

title: Used Summer Bridge Books from PK to 10th grade
body: I've been using these Summer Bridge books for the past 10 or so years. They are a good supplement for summer activities. I do periodic reviews (about 1-2 weeks) to see where my kids are. Some are on top of it, some fall behind and we help them catch up. I tear the Answer Keys out and only use them at reviews. If a kid finishes all their books (including Bonuses) before the school year, they are rewarded - $50 or so. I have also used additional supplemental books, but at times this became too much for them, the Summer Bridge books tend to be more "manageable".

profile.name: MMB Mama

title: Happily crossing the Summer Bridge
body: I read mixed reviews about this product but all in all in must say this product is PERFECT for your pre-schooler enter kindergarten. I am an educator and work will my daughter daily so that she stays ahead of the game and she's not even going to kindergarten yet. As others have stated, sure there are concepts that she has mastered already like basic shape tracing and coloring, but it is still cognitively engaging for her. I skip around the book and we review skills she has already mastered and there are also new concepts that she has begun to work on. Someone also made a comment about the directions and children not being able to read them, I thought about that as well but that where WE come in as the guardians, they should be working on materials with supervision; not only for directions read but also for praise and positive reinforcement. I purchased other books to work with her over the summer as well, and sure she finishes few pages a day in This book, but what I most appreciate is the engagement and how the book is broken up into sections, math skills, science project suggestions, letter sounds and sight words, patterns and scientific concepts and is very colorful. I say get the book. IT is worth it. You want learning to be fun so kids want to continue working. I love the fact that she has mastered some of the sills already outlined in the book, it builds her confidence as she tackles other portions of the book. I wouldn't use this book as my only book for the summer, I would supplement it with additional books/materials as well. I have a separate book just for math, sight words and language arts.

title: Wonderful Christmas book
body: I recently read the book We're Going on a Sleigh Ride absolutely loved it! The lift-the-flap format of the book is a great way to engage young readers and keep them entertained throughout the story. The illustrations are colorful and delightful, and the rhyming text is fun to read aloud. The story follows a group of bunnies as they go on a sleigh ride and encounter various winter animals along the way. My favorite part was when they met a polar bear and had to think of a clever way to get past him.  Overall, I would highly recommend this book to parents with young children. It's a great addition to any child's book collection and is sure to be a hit at bedtime.
body_html:
I recently read the book We're Going on a Sleigh Ride absolutely loved it! The lift-the-flap format of the book is a great way to engage young readers and keep them entertained throughout the story. The illustrations are colorful and delightful, and the rhyming text is fun to read aloud. The story follows a group of bunnies as they go on a sleigh ride and encounter various winter animals along the way. My favorite part was when they met a polar bear and had to think of a clever way to get past him.

Overall, I would highly recommend this book to parents with young children. It's a great addition to any child's book collection and is sure to be a hit at bedtime.

profile.name: El

title: Run out of Midsummer Murders? drive north a county or two!
body: A well crafted ‘cosy’ pitched between Trollope, Chesterton and Caroline Graham. The story flows while nailing the characters without over descriptive character development. There is enough Latin and ecclesiastical terms to be relevant to the churched - not enough to be a stumbling block for others. There is an abundance of story based on well observed humanity. Richard Coles knows his county - the English Civil War boundaries do still stand 400+ years later! It’s set in 1988 (another year of Luton Town footballing accomplishment) - a time when even the ‘spare son’ of the landed gentry couldn’t afford to be open about his lasting love affair with another man. But more corrosive was the shame of previous generations born out of marriage and wartime secrets. Woven in, seamlessly, are themes of past sins revealing themselves, offence and murder, how the smaller losses of the present may rekindle heartbreaking losses of the past, justice and mercy, forgiveness and coming to a shared peace after such turmoil. Fr Daniel’s formidable mother, actor brother and growing friendship with the Detective Sergeant form a solid based for the Rector’s crime solving observations. Great holiday reading. As bed time reading, beware the “just one more chapter” trap - you’ll enjoyably read into the early hours.
body_html:
A well crafted ‘cosy’ pitched between Trollope, Chesterton and Caroline Graham. The story flows while nailing the characters without over descriptive character development. There is enough Latin and ecclesiastical terms to be relevant to the churched - not enough to be a stumbling block for others. There is an abundance of story based on well observed humanity. Richard Coles knows his county - the English Civil War boundaries do still stand 400+ years later!
It’s set in 1988 (another year of Luton Town footballing accomplishment) - a time when even the ‘spare son’ of the landed gentry couldn’t afford to be open about his lasting love affair with another man. But more corrosive was the shame of previous generations born out of marriage and wartime secrets.
Woven in, seamlessly, are themes of past sins revealing themselves, offence and murder, how the smaller losses of the present may rekindle heartbreaking losses of the past, justice and mercy, forgiveness and coming to a shared peace after such turmoil.
Fr Daniel’s formidable mother, actor brother and growing friendship with the Detective Sergeant form a solid based for the Rector’s crime solving observations.
Great holiday reading. As bed time reading, beware the “just one more chapter” trap - you’ll enjoyably read into the early hours.

profile.name: Francophile

title: Plodding murder mystery
body: Stories about sleuthing clerics are nothing new, Father Brown being perhaps the best known. But one written by an actual Church of England vicar – albeit one who is a former Communard and a regular on radio and TV panel shows – is a bit different.  Canon Daniel Clements wants to bring the parish of Champton St Mary up to date by installing a toilet at the back of the church. Members of the congregation, in particular the powerful Flower Guild, are opposed. Perhaps an unlikely background to murder but still…  The story plays out in a sort of timeless Middle England, although the cultural references place it firmly in the 1980s. Champton may not be St Mary Mead but there’s more than a hint of Miss Marple here in the depiction of the undercurrents and rivalries of village life.  The writing is quite good with some nice descriptive passages but the pace is doggedly pedestrian. You’re about a third of the way in before anyone gets killed and even as you approach the denouement it continues at a steady plod. There are a lot of rather two-dimensional characters many of whom don’t bring much, if anything, to the plot. In fact Daniel’s dogs are more fully rounded than some of the human players. It doesn’t really work well as a whodunnit either as there are few hints at the identity of the killer.  I was looking forward to reading this but I have to say it left me rather disappointed. It’s hard to escape the conclusion that if it didn’t have a celebrity name attached it might have struggled to find a publisher.
body_html:
Stories about sleuthing clerics are nothing new, Father Brown being perhaps the best known. But one written by an actual Church of England vicar – albeit one who is a former Communard and a regular on radio and TV panel shows – is a bit different.

Canon Daniel Clements wants to bring the parish of Champton St Mary up to date by installing a toilet at the back of the church. Members of the congregation, in particular the powerful Flower Guild, are opposed. Perhaps an unlikely background to murder but still…

The story plays out in a sort of timeless Middle England, although the cultural references place it firmly in the 1980s. Champton may not be St Mary Mead but there’s more than a hint of Miss Marple here in the depiction of the undercurrents and rivalries of village life.

The writing is quite good with some nice descriptive passages but the pace is doggedly pedestrian. You’re about a third of the way in before anyone gets killed and even as you approach the denouement it continues at a steady plod. There are a lot of rather two-dimensional characters many of whom don’t bring much, if anything, to the plot. In fact Daniel’s dogs are more fully rounded than some of the human players. It doesn’t really work well as a whodunnit either as there are few hints at the identity of the killer.

I was looking forward to reading this but I have to say it left me rather disappointed. It’s hard to escape the conclusion that if it didn’t have a celebrity name attached it might have struggled to find a publisher.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 January 2024
profile.name: christina

title: Cosy crime in need of a caffe ristretto
body: As I love crime novels – Ann Cleeves, Peter Lovesey, Anthony Horowitz, Elly Griffiths - I really wanted to like this, but it was disappointing.  There’s plenty of expert advice online for a budding author wanting to know how to get published in crime fiction, such as, “be clear about the time period, and don’t overwhelm your readers with too many characters in the early chapters.” Oops. Here, the decade in which the plot unfolds is unclear from the get go, which is disconcerting. And so many villagers are thrown at you at the beginning that the book only becomes a page turner when you start flicking backwards to find out who they all are. When the first murder took place, I couldn’t immediately place who the victim was. The murder itself was an event so long coming that in the meantime I began to come up with alternative titles for the book. Then there’s the problem with the main protagonist - Canon Clement. Proactive he is not. Two thirds of the way through, his mother comments on how good at detecting he is when, to my mind, he hasn’t done any.  Now I really like the Reverend Richard Coles and he has a winning writing style, but his publisher has done him a disservice by not being strict enough in the editing. If this manuscript had arrived anonymously in the slush pile, would it have got this far this quickly? For a first-time fiction author, the potential is there, so why wasn’t there more input to make this, the Reverend Coles’ first book, the best it could be? I’m merely a reader but I can see the flaws, so what blinded the publishers to them? Could it be they rushed everything through hoping for instant success on the back of Richard Osman’s excellent Thursday Club series? Well, it worked in a way because this book is a best seller. What it isn’t is a page turner.  If Weidenfield and Nicolson want a successful series, they’d better get a grip, otherwise, they’ll leave themselves open to the charge that the obvious answer to the budding author’s question of how to get published in crime fiction, is “First become a celebrity.”
body_html:
As I love crime novels – Ann Cleeves, Peter Lovesey, Anthony Horowitz, Elly Griffiths - I really wanted to like this, but it was disappointing.

There’s plenty of expert advice online for a budding author wanting to know how to get published in crime fiction, such as, “be clear about the time period, and don’t overwhelm your readers with too many characters in the early chapters.” Oops. Here, the decade in which the plot unfolds is unclear from the get go, which is disconcerting. And so many villagers are thrown at you at the beginning that the book only becomes a page turner when you start flicking backwards to find out who they all are. When the first murder took place, I couldn’t immediately place who the victim was. The murder itself was an event so long coming that in the meantime I began to come up with alternative titles for the book. Then there’s the problem with the main protagonist - Canon Clement. Proactive he is not. Two thirds of the way through, his mother comments on how good at detecting he is when, to my mind, he hasn’t done any.

Now I really like the Reverend Richard Coles and he has a winning writing style, but his publisher has done him a disservice by not being strict enough in the editing. If this manuscript had arrived anonymously in the slush pile, would it have got this far this quickly? For a first-time fiction author, the potential is there, so why wasn’t there more input to make this, the Reverend Coles’ first book, the best it could be? I’m merely a reader but I can see the flaws, so what blinded the publishers to them? Could it be they rushed everything through hoping for instant success on the back of Richard Osman’s excellent Thursday Club series? Well, it worked in a way because this book is a best seller. What it isn’t is a page turner.

If Weidenfield and Nicolson want a successful series, they’d better get a grip, otherwise, they’ll leave themselves open to the charge that the obvious answer to the budding author’s question of how to get published in crime fiction, is “First become a celebrity.”

title: Set in the 1980's
body: Once you catch onto the fact that the book is set in the 1980's it makes a bit more sense. This is quite an enjoyable read, but I found myself getting confused to as to who was who and had to keep flicking back to previous chapters to find out how X was related to Y. Canon Clement is a very likable character who lives with his 2 dachsunds (in more than a nod to the author) and his feisty mum, Audrey. I'm not sure whether I would read the next one though.

title: Slow and steady.
body: Slow to get going, too many long ecclesiastical words, too much filler in the way of dog stories. A kind of Midsomer Murders via Heartbeat and All Gas and Gaiters.
body_html: Slow to get going, too many long ecclesiastical words, too much filler in the way of dog stories. A kind of Midsomer Murders via Heartbeat and All Gas and Gaiters.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 16 April 2024
profile.name: Lesley Mc

title: A gripping story of redemption, love, and loyalty
body: ‘Love - love was a balm as much as it was a poison.'  This series has been nothing short of spectacular. Here we are on the third book and none of the pace, passion or heart stopping moments have abated. If anything, they’ve intensified. A Court of Wind and Ruin was brilliant. Exhilarating! Unputdownable! We’ve loved it all!  "Wanting you - every hour, every breath. I don't think I can stand a thousand years of this."  It's one thing to put words on paper, but it's a whole other creative talent that brings the magic, the imagination, and the words so exquisitely to life. We could picture everything and revelled in the suspense thrilling conclusion to the story so far. We couldn’t breathe whilst reading this book!  A year has passed since Feyre Acheron entered faery and her life has changed in so many dramatic and unexpected ways. Her relationship with Rhysand, her mate, and his band of loyal friends, Azriel, Cassian, Mor and Amren are one built on loyalty and love. All play their part in this third instalment as faery is once again poised on the brink of war. It’s tense, page turning stuff!  “I see all of you, Rhys. And there is not one part that I do not love with everything that I am.” “You bow to no one,” was all he replied.  We learn more about Feyre’s sister Nesta and Elain who feature heavily in this book, together with Lucian and his past – it was all so emotional, exciting, and frustrating in equal measures.  “To the stars who listen - and the dreams that are answered.”  Sarah J Maas is a master storyteller, of that there is no question. The impending war were delivered with gut twisting suspense; the fight scenes themselves were on another level. We can’t describe just how good they were. We both declared them as being some of THE best scenes we’ve ever read in a fantasy paranormal, and we’ve read a lot!  "You do not fear," Rhys breathed. "You do not falter. You do not yield."  We revelled in how it played out - we couldn’t' have asked for more. We felt as though we were a part of this story, like we were reading in ‘real’ time, experiencing the story with the characters, and as avid readers, we couldn’t have asked for more.  A gripping story of redemption, love, and loyalty, where friend and foe tread a very thin line, leaving us gasping at some of the twists and turns. Rhysand still has our hearts. A born protector who would sacrifice his life for those he loves. This man has it all!  "I believe that everything happened, exactly the way it had to ..so I could find you."
body_html:
‘Love - love was a balm as much as it was a poison.'

This series has been nothing short of spectacular. Here we are on the third book and none of the pace, passion or heart stopping moments have abated. If anything, they’ve intensified. A Court of Wind and Ruin was brilliant. Exhilarating! Unputdownable! We’ve loved it all!

"Wanting you - every hour, every breath. I don't think I can stand a thousand years of this."

It's one thing to put words on paper, but it's a whole other creative talent that brings the magic, the imagination, and the words so exquisitely to life. We could picture everything and revelled in the suspense thrilling conclusion to the story so far. We couldn’t breathe whilst reading this book!

A year has passed since Feyre Acheron entered faery and her life has changed in so many dramatic and unexpected ways. Her relationship with Rhysand, her mate, and his band of loyal friends, Azriel, Cassian, Mor and Amren are one built on loyalty and love. All play their part in this third instalment as faery is once again poised on the brink of war. It’s tense, page turning stuff!

“I see all of you, Rhys. And there is not one part that I do not love with everything that I am.”
“You bow to no one,” was all he replied.

We learn more about Feyre’s sister Nesta and Elain who feature heavily in this book, together with Lucian and his past – it was all so emotional, exciting, and frustrating in equal measures.

“To the stars who listen - and the dreams that are answered.”

Sarah J Maas is a master storyteller, of that there is no question. The impending war were delivered with gut twisting suspense; the fight scenes themselves were on another level. We can’t describe just how good they were. We both declared them as being some of THE best scenes we’ve ever read in a fantasy paranormal, and we’ve read a lot!

"You do not fear," Rhys breathed. "You do not falter. You do not yield."

We revelled in how it played out - we couldn’t' have asked for more. We felt as though we were a part of this story, like we were reading in ‘real’ time, experiencing the story with the characters, and as avid readers, we couldn’t have asked for more.

A gripping story of redemption, love, and loyalty, where friend and foe tread a very thin line, leaving us gasping at some of the twists and turns. Rhysand still has our hearts. A born protector who would sacrifice his life for those he loves. This man has it all!

"I believe that everything happened, exactly the way it had to ..so I could find you."
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 March 2024
profile.name: GG

title: Mesmerising Adult Fairy Tale - Terrific
body: Welcome to the Court of Adult Fairy Tales, with 5 stars for the latest instalment from the breath-taking series written by Sarah Maas (The Court of Thorns and Roses). And now the Court of Wings and Ruin transports us yet again into this adult fairy tale world and on journey of danger and triumph that is action packed and alluring, and where wisdom, betrayal, loyalty, and love, feature heavily in the story.  Another spell binding story from an author whose imagination appears limitless, a story that is told with a vast range of intriguing characters, a plot that is superb in its concept and delivery and with a level of suspense that will rival the best thrillers. Absorbing, captivating, and compulsive as we remain entrapped in Maas's world of High Fae and the Court of Thorns and Roses.  The Plot  Think, plan, believe, be ready. Organise, prepare, trust and be on guard.  And yet they were not ready, and the Night Court, including Rhys and Feyre, had not foreseen the alliances that were being forged around them and Tamlin is making deals with the invading king of Hybern threatening to bring Prythian to its knees. However, close to the ‘Wall’, the southern territories and the human lands are most at risk from the Hybern onslaught. Yet the wall came down and the Night Court was left defending its court. The enemy used the element of surprise to their advantage and even with the combined physical and mental skills of the Night Court inner circle, victory seemed the stuff of dreams.  There is so much happening in every chapter it is difficult to summarise all the sub plots, twists, and storylines. Suffice to say the seven courts are in play and we are moving towards the major battle, where fittest and most courageous will get to write the ending. A difficult feat because no one Lord can achieve this on their own, but it is difficult to know where loyalties lie.  Review and Comments  Wings and Ruin, brought so many conflicts yet it is an epic love story, much of the earth was scorched and weary from battle yet the story and setting continues to be enchanting, the characters are scheming but deliciously flawed and likeable and the writing is just stunning where I have to conclude that not a word could be written differently.  That said, I cannot lavish enough praise on this series, it is truly awesome and one I would have enjoyed before embracing Fantasy more readily. Formidable, mesmerising, jaw droppingly beautiful  Sarah Maas has one hell of an imagination that just blows me away and with three brilliant books so far, I have to say from my own experience, Maas is the Queen of Fantasy.
body_html:
Welcome to the Court of Adult Fairy Tales, with 5 stars for the latest instalment from the breath-taking series written by Sarah Maas (The Court of Thorns and Roses). And now the Court of Wings and Ruin transports us yet again into this adult fairy tale world and on journey of danger and triumph that is action packed and alluring, and where wisdom, betrayal, loyalty, and love, feature heavily in the story.

Another spell binding story from an author whose imagination appears limitless, a story that is told with a vast range of intriguing characters, a plot that is superb in its concept and delivery and with a level of suspense that will rival the best thrillers. Absorbing, captivating, and compulsive as we remain entrapped in Maas's world of High Fae and the Court of Thorns and Roses.

The Plot

Think, plan, believe, be ready.
Organise, prepare, trust and be on guard.

And yet they were not ready, and the Night Court, including Rhys and Feyre, had not foreseen the alliances that were being forged around them and Tamlin is making deals with the invading king of Hybern threatening to bring Prythian to its knees. However, close to the ‘Wall’, the southern territories and the human lands are most at risk from the Hybern onslaught. Yet the wall came down and the Night Court was left defending its court. The enemy used the element of surprise to their advantage and even with the combined physical and mental skills of the Night Court inner circle, victory seemed the stuff of dreams.

There is so much happening in every chapter it is difficult to summarise all the sub plots, twists, and storylines. Suffice to say the seven courts are in play and we are moving towards the major battle, where fittest and most courageous will get to write the ending. A difficult feat because no one Lord can achieve this on their own, but it is difficult to know where loyalties lie.

Review and Comments

Wings and Ruin, brought so many conflicts yet it is an epic love story, much of the earth was scorched and weary from battle yet the story and setting continues to be enchanting, the characters are scheming but deliciously flawed and likeable and the writing is just stunning where I have to conclude that not a word could be written differently.

That said, I cannot lavish enough praise on this series, it is truly awesome and one I would have enjoyed before embracing Fantasy more readily. Formidable, mesmerising, jaw droppingly beautiful

Sarah Maas has one hell of an imagination that just blows me away and with three brilliant books so far, I have to say from my own experience, Maas is the Queen of Fantasy.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 January 2022
profile.name: MM Reviewer

title: 4 Stars - Great Third Installment
body: So, in my reviews for ACOTAR and ACOMAF I mentioned how a book should give you the feels – it should influence you emotionally if it’s doing its job properly; well, this one had tears streaming down my face for the entire last 10%. There were happy tears and sad tears and the entire damn thing took over my consciousness for the 10 days or so over which I consumed it.  It’s a young adult fantasy novel but unlike YA’s like Fangirl I feel like, because of the more diverse subject matter, as an adult it’s so easy to get immersed in the story – particularly as it takes place within a completely new world. The novel explores issues on a personal level and even goes so far as to introduce younger readers to really tactical approaches to war and conflict. Maas draws inspiration from all over, the Oroboros springing out of Egyptian mythology and other references popping up throughout (the Myrmidons from the siege of Troy, remodelling the ancient Greek ‘Illyrians’ and other references from the bible, Greek mythology and Russian folktale.) This weaving together of fantasy and history adds richness to the text and is part of the reason I found the second and third books so much more interesting to read. #NerdAlert – sorry, not sorry. And, actually, the way Maas wove plot elements from the first and second books into the key events of this third instalment was fabulous in itself. The plot was definitely interesting enough (and full of enough twists and turns) to keep me hooked from chapter one until the very last page.  I found myself highlighting so many passages out of sheer love of what was written (don’t worry I was reading using kindle so I didn’t deface any books!), I really enjoyed Maas’ writing, more so than I did in the first and second books. Plot wise, ACOMAF still remains my favourite because the whole Feyre- Rhysand escapade was just perfect and I totally shipped them in book one (sorry Tamlin!) They just made so much sense and the way they respected each other and even went so far as to make each other better really stood out as a winning trait for an already likeable and bad-ass pairing.  “the male who had always presented me with a choice not as a gift, but as my own gods-given right.” I didn’t find their relationship as compelling in this third book however. The whole mating thing is something I’m a bit conflicted about. I mean, on one hand it’s totally sweet and it’s like their souls are connected and whatever and it makes for interesting writing (where there’s a mating bond but someone doesn’t want to accept it) but I don’t know. It kind of just belittled the idea of ‘love’ and really reminded me of the imprinting thing in Twilight. Feels like it’s going that way too: Feyre’s going to get pregnant with a crazy, super-strong, night court baby and Azriel’s going to imprint *cough, sorry* have a mating bond with it or something. Whilst it’d be cute to see Rhysand all cute and protective I just don’t wholly like it – the mating thing is something I can’t decide if i like or not.  But that’s not the only reason their relationship is less rivetting: there was no “will they, won’t they” so much of their interaction was a bit dull (except that tense scene near the end – omg). The sex scenes in particular were a little unnecessary and awkward and I’m definitely glad there were less than in the second book. (They often felt a bit over-written – like, they had sex, I get it, she doesn’t need to be shining like a beacon or making the mountain tremble. I mean really, *eyeroll*. But then, this book wasn’t as much ‘about’ them – it was about saving the world which *I GUESS* is kind of important too… I still love them though. On a complete tangent I actually still like Tamlin (not for Feyre, obviously) and think he’s a complex and interesting character to read about – he’s flawed like anyone else but ultimately shows his true colours in this, the third book .  The third book really doesn’t disappoint – whilst much of the ‘action’ happens in the last 10% of the book every focal character had a difficulty they were facing and their own issues to contend with along with the main plot and this made them far, far more interesting than they may otherwise have been. And Maas deals with PTSD well – she does not pretend that the hardships faced by her characters does not affect them but also reminds us that it does not make them weak – an important message. I adore every member of the night court not only for their love of one-another but for the sheer selflessness they all exude. It promotes such a healthy message (though I wont deny a little selfishness from someone might’ve made the characters a bit more diverse and believable.) Actually, there were mistakes made by night court members but it was mostly just Feyre who made mistakes and had regrets. A lot of her choices in the first 10% of the novel were definitely up for contention but I think ultimately, they reflect (and are a result of) her suffering in the previous two books and the plot simply builds her character and extends those emotions beyond just telling us how she feels. But, that’s the night court for you – secret guardians of peace in Prythian (with a handful of misbehaviour and more than a sprinkle of sass).  They weren’t the only court I liked though! Learning about the other courts was great fun and made me just want to get out the pencils and paints and try my hand at some fan art. The series does really have a great way of inviting fandom (as well as both bad and good discussion) – it’s a series readers want to talk about with other people, to write fanfiction on and to continue experiencing in every way possible – and that really is a testament to Maas’ ability to generate characters we care about. Even characters who were ugly, mythical and somewhat disturbing became lovable in this novel. I cared about the Suriel, learned to understand The Bone Carver and became attached to a creature so terrifying and gruesome it even sent Cassian screaming in fear. Maas frequently takes our expectations of characters and flips them on their heads and it’s really well done throughout the ACOWAR.  A lot of readers don’t like the series, or Maas’ writing and I definitely understand that – I definitely could have swung that way after reading the first book. There are definitely a few things that annoy me about her writing and the way she does things – I haven’t read the Throne of Glass series because I haven’t managed to get through the first book yet. Maas, like most writers, has flaws but For me, this was a good story and I really connected with the characters – it let me forget the things I didn’t like so much. But if you experienced the series differently and hated it I want to hear about it too. This book is such a topic of discussion for many readers and it’s good to talk about the different issues it deals with. I really did not like Everything, Everything by Nicola Yoon but lots of people loved it so I definitely know what it’s like the be on the opposing side of a fandom – reading is such an individual experience, it’s important to have your own response; your opinions are personal to you.  Overall, I really enjoyed this series and look forward to hearing more about the Court of Dreams characters in the future. The events at the end of this book temporarily broke me for the 20 minutes or so during which I inhaled the words! Ultimately, if you’re a fan of Maas and liked the second book, I can’t see why you wouldn’t like this one.

I didn’t find their relationship as compelling in this third book however. The whole mating thing is something I’m a bit conflicted about. I mean, on one hand it’s totally sweet and it’s like their souls are connected and whatever and it makes for interesting writing (where there’s a mating bond but someone doesn’t want to accept it) but I don’t know. But that’s not the only reason their relationship is less rivetting: there was no “will they, won’t they” so much of their interaction was a bit dull (except that tense scene near the end – omg). The sex scenes in particular were a little unnecessary and awkward and I’m definitely glad there were less than in the second book. (They often felt a bit over-written – like, they had sex, I get it, she doesn’t need to be shining like a beacon or making the mountain tremble. I mean really, *eyeroll*. But then, this book wasn’t as much ‘about’ them – it was about saving the world which *I GUESS* is kind of important too… I still love them though. On a complete tangent I actually still like Tamlin (not for Feyre, obviously) and think he’s a complex and interesting character to read about – he’s flawed like anyone else but ultimately shows his true colours in this, the third book .

The third book really doesn’t disappoint – whilst much of the ‘action’ happens in the last 10% of the book every focal character had a difficulty they were facing and their own issues to contend with along with the main plot and this made them far, far more interesting than they may otherwise have been. And Maas deals with PTSD well – she does not pretend that the hardships faced by her characters does not affect them but also reminds us that it does not make them weak – an important message. I adore every member of the night court not only for their love of one-another but for the sheer selflessness they all exude. It promotes such a healthy message (though I wont deny a little selfishness from someone might’ve made the characters a bit more diverse and believable.) Actually, there were mistakes made by night court members but it was mostly just Feyre who made mistakes and had regrets. A lot of her choices in the first 10% of the novel were definitely up for contention but I think ultimately, they reflect (and are a result of) her suffering in the previous two books and the plot simply builds her character and extends those emotions beyond just telling us how she feels. But, that’s the night court for you – secret guardians of peace in Prythian (with a handful of misbehaviour and more than a sprinkle of sass).

They weren’t the only court I liked though! Learning about the other courts was great fun and made me just want to get out the pencils and paints and try my hand at some fan art. The series does really have a great way of inviting fandom (as well as both bad and good discussion) – it’s a series readers want to talk about with other people, to write fanfiction on and to continue experiencing in every way possible – and that really is a testament to Maas’ ability to generate characters we care about. Even characters who were ugly, mythical and somewhat disturbing became lovable in this novel. I cared about the Suriel, learned to understand The Bone Carver and became attached to a creature so terrifying and gruesome it even sent Cassian screaming in fear. Maas frequently takes our expectations of characters and flips them on their heads and it’s really well done throughout the ACOWAR.

A lot of readers don’t like the series, or Maas’ writing and I definitely understand that – I definitely could have swung that way after reading the first book. There are definitely a few things that annoy me about her writing and the way she does things – I haven’t read the Throne of Glass series because I haven’t managed to get through the first book yet. Maas, like most writers, has flaws but For me, this was a good story and I really connected with the characters – it let me forget the things I didn’t like so much. But if you experienced the series differently and hated it I want to hear about it too. This book is such a topic of discussion for many readers and it’s good to talk about the different issues it deals with. I really did not like Everything, Everything by Nicola Yoon but lots of people loved it so I definitely know what it’s like the be on the opposing side of a fandom – reading is such an individual experience, it’s important to have your own response; your opinions are personal to you.

Overall, I really enjoyed this series and look forward to hearing more about the Court of Dreams characters in the future. The events at the end of this book temporarily broke me for the 20 minutes or so during which I inhaled the words! Ultimately, if you’re a fan of Maas and liked the second book, I can’t see why you wouldn’t like this one.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 15 September 2017
profile.name: Cat

title: I just love Rhysand and Feyre
body: Feyre is on a mission for vengeance as she leaves the Night Court and faces deceit in a deadly game. With Tamlin making dangerous deals and Prythian at risk, Feyre must navigate a world of lies to uncover his plans. As war looms, she must choose allies wisely among the High Lords and find unexpected help.  The vivid scenery and enchanting world of Prythian come to life in Maas’ writing, with new places explored and characters evolving. The characters, both beloved and feared, shine in their complexity and depth. Maas’ writing is flawless, with intricate storytelling that captivates readers and builds an immersive world.  For fans of the series, A Court of Wings and Ruin is a satisfying finale that surpasses its predecessors. Maas’ talent shines in this epic conclusion, leaving readers eager for more of her incredible storytelling.
body_html:
Feyre is on a mission for vengeance as she leaves the Night Court and faces deceit in a deadly game. With Tamlin making dangerous deals and Prythian at risk, Feyre must navigate a world of lies to uncover his plans. As war looms, she must choose allies wisely among the High Lords and find unexpected help.

The vivid scenery and enchanting world of Prythian come to life in Maas’ writing, with new places explored and characters evolving. The characters, both beloved and feared, shine in their complexity and depth. Maas’ writing is flawless, with intricate storytelling that captivates readers and builds an immersive world.

For fans of the series, A Court of Wings and Ruin is a satisfying finale that surpasses its predecessors. Maas’ talent shines in this epic conclusion, leaving readers eager for more of her incredible storytelling.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 April 2024
profile.name: Tanita Dawn De Bruyn

title: The best out of the 5
body: I really enjoyed this series, despite sometimes finding the writing a little sloppy, the imagination and ability to keep you on the edge of your seat is totally there. This is the best book out of all 5 for sure, unpopular opinion considering that people usually favour ACOMAF. However, the action in ACOWAR is incredibly exciting, the war itself, the twists, the relationships created with the Suriel, the Bone Carver, Bryaxis and The Weaver. The meeting of all the High Lords was one of my favourite chapters, especially meeting Helion! The inner circle of the Night Court are great characters that I never get tired of, especially Amren, whose dark edge reminds me of myself. The bond between Feyre and Rhysand continues to be electric, and with the twist near the end this book had me sobbing, can’t remember the last time I cried over a book. Give it a read, it’ll be hard to find your way back to regular life after, but that’s what books are for anyway.

Give it a read, it’ll be hard to find your way back to regular life after, but that’s what books are for anyway.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 April 2024
profile.name: Fleur Paller

title: Speechless, just incredible.
body: Wow. Just, wow. I was speechless when I finished the book. It was honestly incredible. I really thoroughly enjoyed this one; I may even like it more than A Court of Mist and Fury!  The reason I think I enjoyed it every slightly more than A Court of Mist and Fury is because I felt like the story just kicked in from the first page and didn’t stop until the last. I was sucked into the story from the very beginning; I took me a few chapters to really get into ACOMAF (for some reason 🤷‍♀️).  So. Freaking. Much. Happens. Feyre and Rhys’ reunion may possibly be among my favourite scenes from any book. It was everything and I loved it. I love their relationship so damn much. The whole book was such a rollercoaster; I think I went through every emotion possible.  Being a massive fan of the Lord of the Rings book series, I love battle/war scenes. In fact, the war scenes reminded me a little of the Battle of the Pelennor Fields from Return of the King. There’s just something about the action and excitement of a battle or war scene. This was one aspect of the book that I really loved; I think it was really well written and was very exciting. I just wanted to keep reading and not put it down for even one second.  The further development of characters was really, really great. I especially loved that we learned more about Mor; she’s a really great character and one of my favourites. I also liked the development of Nesta and Elaine; I found them both a little annoying when they were first introduced to the story again but found myself loving them both by the end. I can’t wait to see where their characters go in the next books.  I cannot wait to read the next two (although, I’m gutted that there are only two left).

So. Freaking. Much. Happens. Feyre and Rhys’ reunion may possibly be among my favourite scenes from any book. It was everything and I loved it. I love their relationship so damn much. The whole book was such a rollercoaster; I think I went through every emotion possible.

Being a massive fan of the Lord of the Rings book series, I love battle/war scenes. In fact, the war scenes reminded me a little of the Battle of the Pelennor Fields from Return of the King. There’s just something about the action and excitement of a battle or war scene. This was one aspect of the book that I really loved; I think it was really well written and was very exciting. I just wanted to keep reading and not put it down for even one second.

The further development of characters was really, really great. I especially loved that we learned more about Mor; she’s a really great character and one of my favourites. I also liked the development of Nesta and Elaine; I found them both a little annoying when they were first introduced to the story again but found myself loving them both by the end. I can’t wait to see where their characters go in the next books.

I cannot wait to read the next two (although, I’m gutted that there are only two left).
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 June 2023
profile.name: imysbookshelf

title: Intense from beginning to end
body: I definitely recommend this series. The third book had quite a few surprises that had you shouting in your head at each one that happened. The story leaves you feeling like a yo-yo with your emotions going up and down. Such a great story that you could almost see vividly in your mind's eye and feel all the emotion that the characters feel. It's totally worth it all.

profile.name: Nicky

title: The First Ever book to make me cry, I’m warning you now. It’s bloody fantastic.
body: Ladies and Gentlemen, we have finally found the first book to make me cry. And I loved every second of it!  I’m obsessed with this series, and I hate that it’s taken me so long to read it , but lord, it was worth the wait. I loved meeting Feyre in ACOTAR. I loved meeting Feysand in ACOMAF, seeing Feyre grow into herself and coming across Rhys’ true personality, but in this book, I loved how I was able to see Feyre truly come into herself as High Lady of the Night Court.  The fact that this book was based entirely on the lead up to the war, and the war itself is just perfect. The detail throughout the pages helped me to fall further in love with all of the characters even more than the first two books. I well and truly felt like with each page, I was falling further and further into the fantasy world. I lose myself in the universe of all series that I read, but I have never been so truly immersed in a series, as I have with this one.  It’s utterly heartbreaking and I was figuratively sat at the edge of my seat throughout the entirety of the book. But I could always count on everyone’s favourite bat boys to make me chuckle and swoon. And wow, the fierce fae women within this book just makes it even better! Mor, Amren and Feyre are such beautifully complex characters that they truly feel like more than just words on paper.  Rating this book 5 ⭐️ honestly does not do it justice.
body_html:
Ladies and Gentlemen, we have finally found the first book to make me cry. And I loved every second of it!

I’m obsessed with this series, and I hate that it’s taken me so long to read it , but lord, it was worth the wait. I loved meeting Feyre in ACOTAR. I loved meeting Feysand in ACOMAF, seeing Feyre grow into herself and coming across Rhys’ true personality, but in this book, I loved how I was able to see Feyre truly come into herself as High Lady of the Night Court.

The fact that this book was based entirely on the lead up to the war, and the war itself is just perfect. The detail throughout the pages helped me to fall further in love with all of the characters even more than the first two books. I well and truly felt like with each page, I was falling further and further into the fantasy world. I lose myself in the universe of all series that I read, but I have never been so truly immersed in a series, as I have with this one.

It’s utterly heartbreaking and I was figuratively sat at the edge of my seat throughout the entirety of the book. But I could always count on everyone’s favourite bat boys to make me chuckle and swoon. And wow, the fierce fae women within this book just makes it even better! Mor, Amren and Feyre are such beautifully complex characters that they truly feel like more than just words on paper.

Rating this book 5 ⭐️ honestly does not do it justice.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 May 2023
profile.name: Olivia

title: A Beautiful Way To Tie Up This Arc Of The Story
body: ’And it was the heart of a dreamer that had ceased beating inside that monstrous chest.’  Before I start this review I just want to admit that I’m writing this review up after also finishing the final two books in the series so my thoughts aren’t as fresh in my mind as usual. Consequently I apologise if I’m not as detailed as usual within this review.  It’s no secret that I’m a fan of all things fae and if you’ve seen any of my reviews for the ’Throne Of Glass’ series then you’ll know that I adored that too. So it’s not exactly surprising to say that I adored this book on the whole; although it does pain me to admit that I simultaneously found myself wishing for slightly more.  If I hadn’t read the ’Throne Of Glass’ books before picking this series up then maybe I’d feel differently. Maybe I’d have adored this series as much as I did that one. Yet there were times throughout this novel where I couldn’t help but draw parallels to events, characters or concepts from that series. I suppose it’s not necessarily a bad thing, as I adored them within the books, yet I do think that it personally stopped certain elements from impacting me as deeply as they should.  By this point in time it pretty much goes without saying that I adored the world and characters that Sarah J Maas created within this series. Everyone is fascinating to learn about, there’s mountains of history to uncover (all of her worlds make me long for stories centred within different eras) and the danger and intrigue is non-stop throughout. The writing, as always, left me spellbound and Feyre truly shown in her new role at the beginning of this book.  The end of the novel tied events up beautifully – in a satisfying manner – and left me curious to discover exactly how the author planned to return to the world. Obviously it’s a setting with the potential for countless stories but it still gave you a sense of things being finalized within certain aspects of the previous storylines.  Personally I can’t help but wonder if this book would have benefitted from a couple of more points of view. Its set within a vast and complex fantasy world and I truly do think that learning more about certain areas of that world could have added to the impact of the plot. Naturally some viewpoints would carry the risk of bringing certain spoilers to light but I can’t help but wish that there was some sort of perspective included from within the Spring Court. If you’ve read the previous two books in the series then you’ll know how greatly Tamlin seems to change and I really long for more insight into that. Perhaps not from his perspective but from someone, at least. Similarly I can’t help but feel that including a viewpoint somehow linked to the human queens could have added to the book. Their motivations and realms feel rather unexplored presently.  Other than that I can’t help but feel like certain major powers were destroyed too swiftly (although I did appreciate the unexpected twist of one of those particular takedowns). And the placement of the sex scenes felt a little unnecessary on occasion (being too exhausted to climb into a bath but being up for amorous activities instead for instance).  On the whole I thoroughly enjoyed this book however and thought it tied the initial arc of the series up beautifully. If you’ve enjoyed the previous instalments within the series then I’m sure that you’ll similarly get swept away once again. With a little more insight and additional perspectives I truly believe that this would have been a five star read for me.
body_html:

profile.name: Charlotte Watkins

title: 4.25 stars
body: 4.25 stars 2.5 spice Right ok. So going into this book I was told that it was long and kinda dull and yes it was long but it was so incredible. I didn't know how to do this review because I didn't... But I'm going to split it up onto the sections of the book so full spoilers ahead. Part 1 The boring part with Tamlin however very cute parts with Rhys and Feyre talking down the bond other than that I didn't care. However looking back I think I should of cares more because the characters in the first part were re-mentioned in the final part and I was very confused. Part 2 The best part. With the first bit with Feyre and Lucien going back to the night court and the fight in the winter court. Them after chapter 14 when the mates are reunited I pretty much sobbed my way through because of how sweet they are. Now at this point I was like mmmh 4.5 stars??? But no. One quick note before I go onto the final part is about the spice in this book. I have heard so many things about the spice in this series so lemme give you a breakdown. Yes it is spicy but not that spicy around 2 chapters in this book had full on spicy scenes along with maybe 4 more little pieces of spice throughout. Part 3 The actual battles. I would say after the big high lord meeting up until the end of the war is probably the most boring part of this book my brain wasn't taking in the information so I literally can't tell you anything other than the suriel dying and her going back to the bone carver and Tamlin saving her from thw Kings Place. Literally all I can remember at this point I was like ok this is now a 4 stars. Then the final ending went and my jaw dropped and I started crying. She did not just try and kill Rhys that's not allowed. It's fine though he's ok now. Then the final meeting with the high lords is what made this book a 4.25 stars. Overall this book is better than the first one but not as good as the second one purely because the ending of the second one is unbeatable.

title: Bittersweet
body: Amazing conclusion (kinda) to Feyre and Rhysand’s story. Although I didn’t enjoy it as much as the previous two books, the last two hundred pages were really good in terms of wrapping everything up and tying it together.  For me, it was the first two thirds of the book that dragged, although that could’ve just been because I was on a book hangover from ACOMAF. Apart from that, I fell in love with the characters and found them carrying me through the story when I got bored of some of the plot points.

title: A disappointing end to the trilogy
body: Continuing on from A Court of Mist and Fury, the story starts with Feyre back in the Spring Court as she acts as a secret spy in Tamlin's kingdom ahead of the coming war with Hybern. Yet if Prythian is to stand any true chance against Hybern, Feyre, Rhysand and the other members of the Night Court are going to have to find ways to gather all the allies they can get. Will all the High Lords be able to find a way to work together, and set aside their differences?  I really enjoyed the first two books of this series and was eager to read this last instalment, however, I have to say I was disappointed in this end to the trilogy and found it coming up pretty short in comparison to its predecessors. For a start the book was unnecessary long, and overall I found it quite a slog to get through, tempted at times to simply give up, and I have to confess that I ended up more skim reading certain parts.  I was intrigued with the set up at the start of the story back in the Spring Court, and think this could have been made to work really well, but in actual fact this first part of the book was pretty poor for me. A lot of this was due to Feyre constantly being portrayed with such super-powers, nothing really felt like a threat or challenge to her, as she just walked over everyone so easily. Also I know Tamlin did act badly in the second book, however, there were reasons as to why he did what he did, and I for one don't think he deserved the complete lack of mercy that Feyre treated him with here.  Indeed, I have to say that overall I didn't really like Feyre's character all that much in this book as a whole. She seemed to have lost all her vulnerabilities, and was just a bit too ruthless and arrogant for me. Its not that she's lost her compassion entirely, but she's very self-absorbed here.  I did enjoy Lucien's character in this book, indeed it may have been my overall favourite portrayal in the book, and that was because unlike so many other characters, Lucien still had his complexities (unfortunately I felt he was under-used in the second half of the story). Other favourites on the other hand, such as most of the Night Court, just were painted a little too immaturely in this book. On the one hand there is this really serious threat portrayed of the impending war, and yet so often these characters are just goofing around and making jokes, acting rather like teenagers if anything, with more interest in their romantic entanglements than anything else. Nor did these romantic sub-plots really lead anywhere though, with no character or relationship development.  Feyre and Rhysand were just too 'sickeningly' in love in this book, Rhysand himself 'too perfect', all the mystery and edge that was so present in the first book and was still maintained in the second despite understanding his character better, lost entirely now and replaced instead by a 'puppyish' character who was just bland and boring in this book (oh and once again we keep being told he is the most powerful high Lord in history, but not once did I get a display of that power). Other aspects felt forced, such as Mor's bisexuality.  Nesta and Elain I thought fared better in this book, with their new cauldron-gifted powers, and there is some interest into what their own stories might hold in future books, however, right now after this book, I'm unsure if I would take a chance and continue with the next proposed trilogy centring on Nesta.  Some of the lesser used characters, particularly those older creatures such as the Bone Carver and the Weaver, did intrigue me, but I just felt there was too much going on in this book, with a lot of convoluted storytelling and sub-plots, and ultimately these characters could have been used better than they were. A lot of the story was strategy centred ahead of the war, with too many new characters introduced and not enough time to really get to know them, like the other High Lords. Even once we got to the war itself it didn't hold my interest as it should have.  Maas continues to tell rather than show a lot of the time, with lots of exposition when it comes to characters' backstories, and whilst in previous books such flaws could be overlooked, here everything just felt too messy for it to work. Oh and the constant use of the word 'mate' in this book was just cringey.  This was just an over-bloated and unengaging book, with none of the character-driven storytelling of the previous two books, such that it ruined what had till now been an enjoyable series and I lost interest in many of the characters I had hitherto really liked. I've given it a 3 stars, but in all honesty it may be a 2.5 stars.
body_html:
Continuing on from A Court of Mist and Fury, the story starts with Feyre back in the Spring Court as she acts as a secret spy in Tamlin's kingdom ahead of the coming war with Hybern. Yet if Prythian is to stand any true chance against Hybern, Feyre, Rhysand and the other members of the Night Court are going to have to find ways to gather all the allies they can get. Will all the High Lords be able to find a way to work together, and set aside their differences?

I really enjoyed the first two books of this series and was eager to read this last instalment, however, I have to say I was disappointed in this end to the trilogy and found it coming up pretty short in comparison to its predecessors. For a start the book was unnecessary long, and overall I found it quite a slog to get through, tempted at times to simply give up, and I have to confess that I ended up more skim reading certain parts.

I was intrigued with the set up at the start of the story back in the Spring Court, and think this could have been made to work really well, but in actual fact this first part of the book was pretty poor for me. A lot of this was due to Feyre constantly being portrayed with such super-powers, nothing really felt like a threat or challenge to her, as she just walked over everyone so easily. Also I know Tamlin did act badly in the second book, however, there were reasons as to why he did what he did, and I for one don't think he deserved the complete lack of mercy that Feyre treated him with here.

Indeed, I have to say that overall I didn't really like Feyre's character all that much in this book as a whole. She seemed to have lost all her vulnerabilities, and was just a bit too ruthless and arrogant for me. Its not that she's lost her compassion entirely, but she's very self-absorbed here.

I did enjoy Lucien's character in this book, indeed it may have been my overall favourite portrayal in the book, and that was because unlike so many other characters, Lucien still had his complexities (unfortunately I felt he was under-used in the second half of the story). Other favourites on the other hand, such as most of the Night Court, just were painted a little too immaturely in this book. On the one hand there is this really serious threat portrayed of the impending war, and yet so often these characters are just goofing around and making jokes, acting rather like teenagers if anything, with more interest in their romantic entanglements than anything else. Nor did these romantic sub-plots really lead anywhere though, with no character or relationship development.

Feyre and Rhysand were just too 'sickeningly' in love in this book, Rhysand himself 'too perfect', all the mystery and edge that was so present in the first book and was still maintained in the second despite understanding his character better, lost entirely now and replaced instead by a 'puppyish' character who was just bland and boring in this book (oh and once again we keep being told he is the most powerful high Lord in history, but not once did I get a display of that power). Other aspects felt forced, such as Mor's bisexuality.

Nesta and Elain I thought fared better in this book, with their new cauldron-gifted powers, and there is some interest into what their own stories might hold in future books, however, right now after this book, I'm unsure if I would take a chance and continue with the next proposed trilogy centring on Nesta.

Some of the lesser used characters, particularly those older creatures such as the Bone Carver and the Weaver, did intrigue me, but I just felt there was too much going on in this book, with a lot of convoluted storytelling and sub-plots, and ultimately these characters could have been used better than they were. A lot of the story was strategy centred ahead of the war, with too many new characters introduced and not enough time to really get to know them, like the other High Lords. Even once we got to the war itself it didn't hold my interest as it should have.

Maas continues to tell rather than show a lot of the time, with lots of exposition when it comes to characters' backstories, and whilst in previous books such flaws could be overlooked, here everything just felt too messy for it to work. Oh and the constant use of the word 'mate' in this book was just cringey.

This was just an over-bloated and unengaging book, with none of the character-driven storytelling of the previous two books, such that it ruined what had till now been an enjoyable series and I lost interest in many of the characters I had hitherto really liked. I've given it a 3 stars, but in all honesty it may be a 2.5 stars.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 November 2020
profile.name: little bookworm

title: “Leave This World A Better Place Than How You Found It”.
body: At first I found this book a little harder to get into, but then Azriel lured me in with all that dark and brooding shadow stuff and I was so hooked. I think it's probably fair to say that the first part of this book is perhaps a little lost. Feyre, as you might remember, has switched sides (but is faking it, obviously because Tamlin...no thanks!), and is in the home of the enemy. That's the Spring Court to you and me. But instead of there being lots of treachery and clever deception from Feyre, she's out of there in no time; a shame because I love some cloak and dagger to keep me interested. But never-mind, because after this it's one hell of a ride and so that missed opportunity was of little consequence.  This third book introduces all the players in the War. Not only has Feyre got to convince a host of High Lords to help her defeat Hybern's Army (which is HUGE!), but she's also got to somehow cover up that little thing about taking a bit of each of their powers for herself to make her some sort of super badass High Lady. Bit tricky. Oh and then there's the small issue of how she's just duped Tamlin and now kind of needs his army too. Terribly sticky situation for Feyre, but absolutely wonderful for us readers - so many new characters, each with excellent back stories (because we all know Maas is a Queen of a good back story woven in), and a particularly creepy Bone Carver and other vicious beasties she might want to get on side. I feel exhausted for them to be perfectly honest but it was delicious!  The characters really come to life in this book with even more complexity than ever before. Whilst I still feel that Mist and Fury really excelled at challenging traditional characters, breaking the mould and generally being a massive improvement on Feyre's badassery, I think this book makes the slightly more secondary characters more exciting. Cassian, Azriel, Mor, Amren, Nesta and Elain get much bigger parts in this story and I really fell in love with each of them rather than just being wrapped up in Feyre and Rhys' situation. I think Maas is really excellent at making you become entirely invested in characters, even those who might seem quite detached from the initial story-line. It makes for such rich world building and I absolutely love it. I can't think of another group of characters in a book who have felt quite so real to me.  This is a bit of a slow burner compared to the previous two books, and given that it's largely focused on finding High Lords and Armies, I think that's probably why. But when the War truly begins, wow - that's fastest my eyes have ever moved across a page! The writing is utterly unstoppable; I felt like I was watching it all happen. It's that bum on the edge of your seat kind of good where you just can't predict which curve-ball is coming at you next. Equally, there are some darker elements which are so exciting and genuinely a little bit chilling. I think this element of Maas' stories is often underrated because her characters are so addictive and often take centre stage, but it was a real tension builder in this book - not to be read in a dark, shadow-filled room though.  I still struggle a little with the romance elements. Not the building of a romance; I think Maas is brilliant at leaving me wanting more in terms of waiting to see what's going to happen between characters. Particularly after Feyre having such a swift change of heart with Tamlin - you just never know what's going to happen and who she'll turn you against! But now that Feyre and Rhys are mated, the sexual tension has kind of fizzled out (despite there being lots of sex) and the sexy scenes for me are really awkward. I think it's the choice of words she sometimes uses like being "claimed" or "branded" that just destroy it for me. It's really obtuse and a bit too yuck for me. But anyway, Cassian saves the day on the romance front - what a heart-throb. Gone are the days when Rhys was my future book boyfriend - Cassian and Azriel are like some sort of heroic Godly duo aren't they?  Definitely a nice finish to the first three books, with lots of elements wrapped up and plenty more still to come. I can't wait for the next one.  Alas, Amren still gives me the heebyjeebies! So creepy.
body_html:
At first I found this book a little harder to get into, but then Azriel lured me in with all that dark and brooding shadow stuff and I was so hooked. I think it's probably fair to say that the first part of this book is perhaps a little lost. Feyre, as you might remember, has switched sides (but is faking it, obviously because Tamlin...no thanks!), and is in the home of the enemy. That's the Spring Court to you and me. But instead of there being lots of treachery and clever deception from Feyre, she's out of there in no time; a shame because I love some cloak and dagger to keep me interested. But never-mind, because after this it's one hell of a ride and so that missed opportunity was of little consequence.

This third book introduces all the players in the War. Not only has Feyre got to convince a host of High Lords to help her defeat Hybern's Army (which is HUGE!), but she's also got to somehow cover up that little thing about taking a bit of each of their powers for herself to make her some sort of super badass High Lady. Bit tricky. Oh and then there's the small issue of how she's just duped Tamlin and now kind of needs his army too. Terribly sticky situation for Feyre, but absolutely wonderful for us readers - so many new characters, each with excellent back stories (because we all know Maas is a Queen of a good back story woven in), and a particularly creepy Bone Carver and other vicious beasties she might want to get on side. I feel exhausted for them to be perfectly honest but it was delicious!

The characters really come to life in this book with even more complexity than ever before. Whilst I still feel that Mist and Fury really excelled at challenging traditional characters, breaking the mould and generally being a massive improvement on Feyre's badassery, I think this book makes the slightly more secondary characters more exciting. Cassian, Azriel, Mor, Amren, Nesta and Elain get much bigger parts in this story and I really fell in love with each of them rather than just being wrapped up in Feyre and Rhys' situation. I think Maas is really excellent at making you become entirely invested in characters, even those who might seem quite detached from the initial story-line. It makes for such rich world building and I absolutely love it. I can't think of another group of characters in a book who have felt quite so real to me.

This is a bit of a slow burner compared to the previous two books, and given that it's largely focused on finding High Lords and Armies, I think that's probably why. But when the War truly begins, wow - that's fastest my eyes have ever moved across a page! The writing is utterly unstoppable; I felt like I was watching it all happen. It's that bum on the edge of your seat kind of good where you just can't predict which curve-ball is coming at you next. Equally, there are some darker elements which are so exciting and genuinely a little bit chilling. I think this element of Maas' stories is often underrated because her characters are so addictive and often take centre stage, but it was a real tension builder in this book - not to be read in a dark, shadow-filled room though.

I still struggle a little with the romance elements. Not the building of a romance; I think Maas is brilliant at leaving me wanting more in terms of waiting to see what's going to happen between characters. Particularly after Feyre having such a swift change of heart with Tamlin - you just never know what's going to happen and who she'll turn you against! But now that Feyre and Rhys are mated, the sexual tension has kind of fizzled out (despite there being lots of sex) and the sexy scenes for me are really awkward. I think it's the choice of words she sometimes uses like being "claimed" or "branded" that just destroy it for me. It's really obtuse and a bit too yuck for me. But anyway, Cassian saves the day on the romance front - what a heart-throb. Gone are the days when Rhys was my future book boyfriend - Cassian and Azriel are like some sort of heroic Godly duo aren't they?

Definitely a nice finish to the first three books, with lots of elements wrapped up and plenty more still to come. I can't wait for the next one.

Alas, Amren still gives me the heebyjeebies! So creepy.

title: There can never be enough smut....
body: A tomb of a book that took me into a world I often wished I could be a part of. Massive marble baths, the ability to summon food, and a big ass library??? The life.  This book took me on twists and turns I really wasn't expecting, with unexpected alliances, shocking betrayals, and not enough smut. I've spent the last few weeks taking every wait at a bus stop, long bath, and delayed Uber to read this book.
