profile.name: Chloe

title: Sarah J. Maas has once again created a masterpiece!
body: Sarah J. Maas has once again created a masterpiece, as always her writing was wonderful to read. The way she is able to build such a vivid and beautiful world is amazing and I was gripped from the first line. At the end of A Court of Mist and Fury we leave Feyre back at the Spring Court and in the heart of enemy territory. I have being looking forward to see Feyre play spy for so long and was so happy to find that it definitely lived up to all of my expectations. I adored that we got to see a lot more of Lucian and I feel like we really got to know his character better. I loved the intense moments between him and Feyre when they don't know whether to trust each other or not, they are just perfection. I'm not sure whether it was supposed to be funny but I really found it hilarious, at one point I just could not stop laughing everyone in my house literally though I was going crazy. Maas really created some epic moments that are just incredibly well done, that I will never forget.  “Night Triumphant - and the Stars Eternal. If he was the sweet, terrifying darkness, I was the glittering light that only his shadows could make clear.”  Now lets get to Rhysand...erm.. what can I even say? OH YES!! HE WAS AMAZING! I loved every single Rhys moment that we got to see and I just love him as a character and even though I didn't think that his character could be developed any more after reading ACOMAF, the way Maas wrote his development blew me away it was phenomenal. Now to all my other favourites, all I'm going to say is I adore them all especially Cassian and Azriel. Again it was pure perfection. Mor and Amren's character development also really went somewhere in this book, I never expected what happens to happen and I am still surprised and amazed at the great things that Sarah J. Maas did.  The plot was so action packed and there was always something happening it was so stressful but in a really really great way, I am so glad that we got to see loads more of the High Lords, that was brilliants and I loved the meeting, I am running out of words to use to describe how amazing things were.  I only had one tiny problem, I really wanted a discussion to happen between Tamlin and Feyre near the end after you know what (No spoilers here, see I am really trying), I just really needed more. Saying that I think that things were left in a great way and I really felt satisfied with the conclusion, and I also think that the way it ended really did justice to this amazing series. I am happy with Feyre and Rhysand's ending but I really hope that we get to see them again even if its just a cameo. They will always be some of my favourite characters of all time.  “It's a rare person to face who they are and not run from it - not be broken by it.”  I definitely ugly cried and I will never get over it. I will go as far to say that part of me died while reading this book. The feels were ridiculous and I have never ever cried like I did when I cried while I read this. I'm not sure where the series is going to go and which characters we will see again but I don't care I will read anything Sarah J. Maas writes and the fact that there is going to be more from this world is enough for me. But honestly do I have to wait another year, what will I do until then.  “I would have waited five hundred more years for you. A thousand years. And if this was all the time we were allowed to have... the wait was worth it.”  Overall I loved it and I'm not sure whether A Court of Mist and Fury is still my favourite or whether this one is but I loved them both, and this series has ruined me I have a feeling that I will never find anything as good as these, I am getting depressed just thinking about it. The only thing left to say is that I highly recommend this series, everyone should read it and I think that even if you don't enjoy the fantasy genre I would be extremely surprised if you didn't like this.  5/5 Stars! (Obviously)
body_html:
Sarah J. Maas has once again created a masterpiece, as always her writing was wonderful to read. The way she is able to build such a vivid and beautiful world is amazing and I was gripped from the first line. At the end of A Court of Mist and Fury we leave Feyre back at the Spring Court and in the heart of enemy territory. I have being looking forward to see Feyre play spy for so long and was so happy to find that it definitely lived up to all of my expectations. I loved the intense moments between him and Feyre when they don't know whether to trust each other or not, they are just perfection. I'm not sure whether it was supposed to be funny but I really found it hilarious, at one point I just could not stop laughing everyone in my house literally though I was going crazy. Maas really created some epic moments that are just incredibly well done, that I will never forget.

“Night Triumphant - and the Stars Eternal.
If he was the sweet, terrifying darkness, I was the glittering light that only his shadows could make clear.”

Now lets get to Rhysand...erm.. what can I even say? OH YES!! HE WAS AMAZING! I loved every single Rhys moment that we got to see and I just love him as a character and even though I didn't think that his character could be developed any more after reading ACOMAF, the way Maas wrote his development blew me away it was phenomenal. Now to all my other favourites, all I'm going to say is I adore them all especially Cassian and Azriel. Again it was pure perfection. Mor and Amren's character development also really went somewhere in this book, I never expected what happens to happen and I am still surprised and amazed at the great things that Sarah J. Maas did.

The plot was so action packed and there was always something happening it was so stressful but in a really really great way, I am so glad that we got to see loads more of the High Lords, that was brilliants and I loved the meeting, I am running out of words to use to describe how amazing things were.

I only had one tiny problem, I really wanted a discussion to happen between Tamlin and Feyre near the end after you know what (No spoilers here, see I am really trying), I just really needed more. Saying that I think that things were left in a great way and I really felt satisfied with the conclusion, and I also think that the way it ended really did justice to this amazing series. I am happy with Feyre and Rhysand's ending but I really hope that we get to see them again even if its just a cameo. They will always be some of my favourite characters of all time.

“It's a rare person to face who they are and not run from it - not be broken by it.”

I definitely ugly cried and I will never get over it. I will go as far to say that part of me died while reading this book. The feels were ridiculous and I have never ever cried like I did when I cried while I read this. I'm not sure where the series is going to go and which characters we will see again but I don't care I will read anything Sarah J. Maas writes and the fact that there is going to be more from this world is enough for me. But honestly do I have to wait another year, what will I do until then.

“I would have waited five hundred more years for you. A thousand years. And if this was all the time we were allowed to have... the wait was worth it.”

Overall I loved it and I'm not sure whether A Court of Mist and Fury is still my favourite or whether this one is but I loved them both, and this series has ruined me I have a feeling that I will never find anything as good as these, I am getting depressed just thinking about it. The only thing left to say is that I highly recommend this series, everyone should read it and I think that even if you don't enjoy the fantasy genre I would be extremely surprised if you didn't like this.

5/5 Stars! (Obviously)

profile.name: casey c corr

title: ACOWAR
body: As this is one of my favourite series I pre-ordered this on Kindle and as soon as midnight rolled around I devoured this book. I think I finished it within a day. By far my most anticipated book of 2017.  ***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***  The story picks up pretty much right where we left off in ACOMAF with Feyre back in the Spring Court and ready to destroy Tamlin. I definitely hyped up this book too much after reading ACOMAF, this one was still really good, but book 2 just blew my mind and I felt this one was missing...something.  Things I loved: -Nesta and Cassian. To be honest I wasn't taken with them in book 2 but this book sealed the deal for me. I really didn't get along with Nesta in book 2 but I loved her to bits in this one. She tells it like it is and doesn't care what anyone thinks. I also thought it was very fitting for her to be the reason for the king's downfall. -All the new character introductions in this book, my favourites being Helion, Kallias and Viviana. -Phenomenal world building and I loved visiting all the courts and how amazing each and every one was. -Loved the revelation about Lucien's metal eye (really reminded me of mad eye moody from Harry Potter) also really liked the twist with Lucien's father being Helion! Can't wait to see what happens there. -My favourite scene was when all the high lords gather for a meeting at the Dawn court. Absolutely brilliant.  Things I didn't really like: -Besides from Rhys, Lucien is by far my favourite character. He was my favourite in ACOTAR and I didn't lose hope for his redemption. However, I felt like he was a bit cheated in this book. He appears in the first half and then isn't seen until the last chapter. With the discovery that Elain is Lucien's mate at the end of book 2 I thought Maas would explore that relationship in this book but they only shared a few sentences between them the whole book so I was sort of confused as the why that even occurred at the end of book 2, but I may be missing the point and hopefully the next book will clear everything up...I hope.  -I know Elain went through hell in ACOMAF, however, she was hardly in this book and when she was she was utterly broken, like an empty shell and I was constantly waiting for everyone to try and help her on her recovery but nothing really happened. I loved Elain in the previous books because she was kind, loving and sweet but something big was missing for her character in this book. Also as it turned out she was a Seer nothing really came of that either, all she did was find the Suriel.  -Another thing which really did not make any sense was the fact that Feyre had the power from all the courts and I felt like she was on the sidelines for most of this book, which was disappointing.  -Mor, I felt like Mor deserved a bit more than what she was given in this book. The revelation that Mor is a Lesbian was, in my opinion, not handled properly. I am gutted as it felt like Maas just threw it in just because all the backlash she was getting. I hope Mor gets her own book and she is finally happy.  -Lastly, I thought at the end with their father was a bit rushed. We have hardly even seen him throughout this series and all he said was 1 sentence before he was done in. I wanted to see him, Elain, Feyre and Nesta reconnect etc.  The thing that made me cry like a baby: The Suriel. I will cry every time. This also really reminded me of Harry Potter with Dobby's death, I have no idea why!  Overall a great conclusion with enough loose ends to continue on with the series (which I can't wait for) Amazing world building, characters and general storyline. I will definitely be picking up more Sarah J Maas.
body_html:
As this is one of my favourite series I pre-ordered this on Kindle and as soon as midnight rolled around I devoured this book. I think I finished it within a day. By far my most anticipated book of 2017.

***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***

The story picks up pretty much right where we left off in ACOMAF with Feyre back in the Spring Court and ready to destroy Tamlin.
I definitely hyped up this book too much after reading ACOMAF, this one was still really good, but book 2 just blew my mind and I felt this one was missing...something.

Things I loved:
-Nesta and Cassian. To be honest I wasn't taken with them in book 2 but this book sealed the deal for me. I really didn't get along with Nesta in book 2 but I loved her to bits in this one. She tells it like it is and doesn't care what anyone thinks. I also thought it was very fitting for her to be the reason for the king's downfall.
-All the new character introductions in this book, my favourites being Helion, Kallias and Viviana.
-Phenomenal world building and I loved visiting all the courts and how amazing each and every one was.
-Loved the revelation about Lucien's metal eye (really reminded me of mad eye moody from Harry Potter) also really liked the twist with Lucien's father being Helion! Can't wait to see what happens there.
-My favourite scene was when all the high lords gather for a meeting at the Dawn court. Absolutely brilliant.

Things I didn't really like:
-Besides from Rhys, Lucien is by far my favourite character. He was my favourite in ACOTAR and I didn't lose hope for his redemption. However, I felt like he was a bit cheated in this book. He appears in the first half and then isn't seen until the last chapter. With the discovery that Elain is Lucien's mate at the end of book 2 I thought Maas would explore that relationship in this book but they only shared a few sentences between them the whole book so I was sort of confused as the why that even occurred at the end of book 2, but I may be missing the point and hopefully the next book will clear everything up...I hope.

-I know Elain went through hell in ACOMAF, however, she was hardly in this book and when she was she was utterly broken, like an empty shell and I was constantly waiting for everyone to try and help her on her recovery but nothing really happened. I loved Elain in the previous books because she was kind, loving and sweet but something big was missing for her character in this book. Also as it turned out she was a Seer nothing really came of that either, all she did was find the Suriel.

-Another thing which really did not make any sense was the fact that Feyre had the power from all the courts and I felt like she was on the sidelines for most of this book, which was disappointing.

-Mor, I felt like Mor deserved a bit more than what she was given in this book. The revelation that Mor is a Lesbian was, in my opinion, not handled properly. I am gutted as it felt like Maas just threw it in just because all the backlash she was getting. I hope Mor gets her own book and she is finally happy.

-Lastly, I thought at the end with their father was a bit rushed. We have hardly even seen him throughout this series and all he said was 1 sentence before he was done in. I wanted to see him, Elain, Feyre and Nesta reconnect etc.

The thing that made me cry like a baby: The Suriel. I will cry every time. This also really reminded me of Harry Potter with Dobby's death, I have no idea why!

Overall a great conclusion with enough loose ends to continue on with the series (which I can't wait for)
Amazing world building, characters and general storyline. I will definitely be picking up more Sarah J Maas.

profile.name: bookish_heights

title: Infinite stars for this incredible story.
body: What an incredible journey I have been on. This trilogy has been phenomenal. I am absolutely gutted to have completed reading all three books and whilst I know there are more books in this series, I cannot imagine this particular story being topped in all honesty. I must say a huge thank you to my good friend for the recommendation - I would have missed out reading something very special if it hadn’t been for her.  This story will always have a special place in my heart. I thought the author wrote this complex and detailed narrative perfectly. There has been so much throughout that has amazed me – all the small details especially. I always enjoy a story that has twists and turns, and I’m in awe how the author penned so many incredible scenes, taking the story in a different direction or progressing it brilliantly… each and every time.  Reading ACOTAR has been incredible from start to finish. All the emotions I've experienced have been fabulous. This journey has been one huge emotional roller coaster ride and I’ve loved every moment (yes, even those heartbreaking scenes). I’ve changed my opinions about characters when I never would have thought it possible, and at times I’ve questioned loyalties. I have laughed, cried, loved and despised. You’ll need to strap yourself in for all the angst - that’s a certainty!!! The characters that I have got to know and come to love are all incredible. I’m certain that we all have our individual favourites but I feel that they all played an important and integral part in the story, and they did so very well indeed.  A Court of Wings and Ruin has got to be my favourite book out of the three. Every chapter was packed with new developments and there are a lot of chapters! I was a bit daunted by the size of this novel in the beginning if I’m honest, but this book is a real page turner and I never took notice of where I was at until I those final few chapters, which was only because I didn’t want my journey to end. It was a struggle to put my kindle down when real life needed my attention.  I don’t often reread books. I think we all have ‘to be read’ lists as long as the River Nile. However, I will be reading this trilogy again – that is for certain. I have a feeling I’ll discover little details that I missed first time round, and I cannot wait to be reminded of my favourite scenes – and there are quite a number of them!  I highly recommend that you read the A Court of Thorns and Roses series. If I could give this series infinite stars I would. This story will quite literally take your breath away and I must admit I’m rather jealous of those reading this for the very first time. I need to repeat that I found this to be a phenomenal story, and I can’t imagine you not enjoying it as much as I have.

title: Brilliant
body: Thoroughly enjoyed this book in the series. Finding out what happens to Freya, after the cliffhanger of the last book was killing me! I did half the physical book, and then the second half I listened to the dramatic version on audio. (Loved that, haven’t heard one of those before).  At some many points in this book my heart was in my throat, I had no idea whether I could relax or not. 😂  I don’t want to say much else in case you haven’t read the others. But I’d recommend the physical book and Audio version were both very good.

profile.name: KatieReadingCorner

title: Quite Phenomenal !
body: Sarah J Maas, is “Quite Phenomenal “ Upon discovering her ACOTAR series, I was rather astounded at the quality of her writing. This genre is clearly her world, in terms of she knows exactly where she is going with it, the depth to her creative imagination just had me glued to the pages that I lost all concept of time, I was literally living in the moment. With so much going on in her narratives, she introduces rather subtly to the reader another aspect of her story that can appear at first insignificant, then it can be a short or a long while later you grasp the meaning behind what her intentions are, that she makes you feel you are in the page you are reading, equally it doesn’t stop, it gets deeper and deeper. Every page is absorbing and informative, hence you just have to keep going soaking it up like a sponge. After reading the first book A Court of Thorns & Roses, I have now purchased everything she has written, so I am going through them in order one at a time. Books are to the mind what exercise is to the body, and I do both. The satisfaction to read Sarah J Maas is as good as how a 10 k run can feel afterwards. The quality of her writing is way ahead of her years in age. I have no doubt she has lots more in store and future publications pending…… I certainly hope so. Thank you Ms Maas.
body_html:
Sarah J Maas, is “Quite Phenomenal “
Upon discovering her ACOTAR series, I was rather astounded at the quality of her writing.
This genre is clearly her world, in terms of she knows exactly where she is going with it, the depth to her creative imagination just had me glued to the pages that I lost all concept of time, I was literally living in the moment.
With so much going on in her narratives, she introduces rather subtly to the reader another aspect of her story that can appear at first insignificant, then it can be a short or a long while later you grasp the meaning behind what her intentions are, that she makes you feel you are in the page you are reading, equally it doesn’t stop, it gets deeper and deeper. Every page is absorbing and informative, hence you just have to keep going soaking it up like a sponge.
After reading the first book A Court of Thorns & Roses, I have now purchased everything she has written, so I am going through them in order one at a time.
Books are to the mind what exercise is to the body, and I do both. The satisfaction to read Sarah J Maas is as good as how a 10 k run can feel afterwards. The quality of her writing is way ahead of her years in age. I have no doubt she has lots more in store and future publications pending…… I certainly hope so. Thank you Ms Maas.

profile.name: Kindle Customer

title: Inconsistent, bloated, and just a bit amateurish really.
body: Despite genuinely liking some parts of this book, I can't give it any higher than three stars because there was SO MUCH wrong with it. Maas has, in previous books (ToG 1 through 3 and ACOTAR being examples), shown herself to be an accomplished writer and storyteller and I'm disappointed that her books seem to be getting worse, not better. They're also getting longer (i.e. bloated and bogged down with material that any other author would NOT get away with in traditional publishing) and released more frequently, so perhaps this accounts for the decline in quality? As I said, there were parts that I liked, and a good story buried under the weight of too many unnecessary side plots, side characters, unsexy sex scenes (sorry, Sarah, but your sex scenes are FAR from erotic, and what are they doing in a book marketed as children's/teen fiction anyway?*) and repetitive narrative embellishments. Seriously - there was SO MUCH repetition in this book that at times the writing felt quite amateurish. Also, stilted, run-on sentences, overuse of ellipses, and questions written without question marks. Where was her editor?  There are going to be more books in the ACO series so I guess that's why so many threads were left open-ended. But the ending concluded very little, and it felt rushed and unsatisfying because of that. The end of a book is NOT the place to introduce several new characters and plot threads, even if they will come up in future books. And this is to say nothing of the poor handling that certain characters and situations got! I'm with parts of the fandom/critical readers of Maas's books in agreeing that there are some VERY problematic aspects to ACOWAR and its predecessors, to do with LGBTQIA representation and stereotyping, race and "feminism". This series gets lauded for its supposedly feminist characters, but the feminism here is surface-level only - start probing the characters' actions, their justifications for certain actions, and the fae society as a whole, and you'll see some big, ugly holes in Maas's worldbuilding and writing. For me, the book falls far short of true feminism.  Now that I've torn into ACOWAR with the parts I disliked, here's what redeemed it to a three star rating.  Prythian, the world it exists in, and the fae courts are great. I loved seeing more of the courts, and the meeting between the inner circle and the other High Lords was one of my favourite parts of the book. I want more of this world - just with more consistent worldbuilding. And some rules about how, exactly, being high fae works (ageing despite supposedly being immortal? Do they all die eventually? What? How?!) The non-high fae creatures were SO interesting. The Death Gods, the Firebird, the Peregryns, the Winter Court creatures - more, please, just less shoehorned in. I liked the dynamic between Cassian and Nesta. I liked Elain's development through the novel. And I liked that Tamlin earns a bit of redemption by the end. Feyre and Rhysand were sort-of interesting when they were interacting with other characters, but for the most part, their interactions together bored me. There was no real conflict in their relationship, and while I'm not a fan of pairing couples up and then having them fight just to inject drama into a narrative, every relationship, however perfect, has its ups and downs. Maas could have made it just a *little* harder for Feyre and Rhysand (especially given the newness of their relationship in a world where so much heavy, awful stuff is going down) without tearing her ship apart - and then some of those sex scenes might have actually felt earned, rather than just being more gratuitous examples of how perfect and special and magical their bond is. (*eyeroll*/*barf*) Likewise, the endless, *endless* ways in which other characters (Lucien, the denizens of Velaris, all the inner circle members at certain points) were written to feel like satellites orbiting and worshipping the Feysand sun REALLY annoyed me. Enough, I know they're perfect, and I know everyone is aware they're perfect - ENOUGH!!!  So yes, I struggled with this book. The pacing felt woefully uneven, and there was just too much wrong with it to make it really enjoyable and satisfying. At times I just couldn't face picking it up. But I finished it, and found parts of it fun. But that's all. I want to love Maas's books - but the last four (QoS, ACOMAF, EoS and now ACOWAR) have left me disappointed.  *About sex scenes in teen books - I don't think sex should be deliberately left out of teen books. But I really don't like the way Maas handles them. They are written fairly graphically (bordering on erotica), there are usually too many of them IMO, and her treatment of sexuality is not consistent or thought through enough to make the representation in these books feel appropriate for a teen audience. I googled "writing sex in teen books" to try and work out my thoughts on this topic, and some of the articles that came up were a big help, particularly the Deliciously Fictitious and Publishing Crawl ones.
body_html:
Despite genuinely liking some parts of this book, I can't give it any higher than three stars because there was SO MUCH wrong with it. Maas has, in previous books (ToG 1 through 3 and ACOTAR being examples), shown herself to be an accomplished writer and storyteller and I'm disappointed that her books seem to be getting worse, not better. They're also getting longer (i.e. bloated and bogged down with material that any other author would NOT get away with in traditional publishing) and released more frequently, so perhaps this accounts for the decline in quality? As I said, there were parts that I liked, and a good story buried under the weight of too many unnecessary side plots, side characters, unsexy sex scenes (sorry, Sarah, but your sex scenes are FAR from erotic, and what are they doing in a book marketed as children's/teen fiction anyway?*) and repetitive narrative embellishments. Seriously - there was SO MUCH repetition in this book that at times the writing felt quite amateurish. Also, stilted, run-on sentences, overuse of ellipses, and questions written without question marks. Where was her editor?

There are going to be more books in the ACO series so I guess that's why so many threads were left open-ended. But the ending concluded very little, and it felt rushed and unsatisfying because of that. The end of a book is NOT the place to introduce several new characters and plot threads, even if they will come up in future books. And this is to say nothing of the poor handling that certain characters and situations got! I'm with parts of the fandom/critical readers of Maas's books in agreeing that there are some VERY problematic aspects to ACOWAR and its predecessors, to do with LGBTQIA representation and stereotyping, race and "feminism". This series gets lauded for its supposedly feminist characters, but the feminism here is surface-level only - start probing the characters' actions, their justifications for certain actions, and the fae society as a whole, and you'll see some big, ugly holes in Maas's worldbuilding and writing. For me, the book falls far short of true feminism.

Now that I've torn into ACOWAR with the parts I disliked, here's what redeemed it to a three star rating.

Prythian, the world it exists in, and the fae courts are great. I loved seeing more of the courts, and the meeting between the inner circle and the other High Lords was one of my favourite parts of the book. I want more of this world - just with more consistent worldbuilding. And some rules about how, exactly, being high fae works (ageing despite supposedly being immortal? Do they all die eventually? What? How?!) The non-high fae creatures were SO interesting. The Death Gods, the Firebird, the Peregryns, the Winter Court creatures - more, please, just less shoehorned in. I liked the dynamic between Cassian and Nesta. I liked Elain's development through the novel. And I liked that Tamlin earns a bit of redemption by the end. Feyre and Rhysand were sort-of interesting when they were interacting with other characters, but for the most part, their interactions together bored me. There was no real conflict in their relationship, and while I'm not a fan of pairing couples up and then having them fight just to inject drama into a narrative, every relationship, however perfect, has its ups and downs. Maas could have made it just a *little* harder for Feyre and Rhysand (especially given the newness of their relationship in a world where so much heavy, awful stuff is going down) without tearing her ship apart - and then some of those sex scenes might have actually felt earned, rather than just being more gratuitous examples of how perfect and special and magical their bond is. (*eyeroll*/*barf*) Likewise, the endless, *endless* ways in which other characters (Lucien, the denizens of Velaris, all the inner circle members at certain points) were written to feel like satellites orbiting and worshipping the Feysand sun REALLY annoyed me. Enough, I know they're perfect, and I know everyone is aware they're perfect - ENOUGH!!!

So yes, I struggled with this book. The pacing felt woefully uneven, and there was just too much wrong with it to make it really enjoyable and satisfying. At times I just couldn't face picking it up. But I finished it, and found parts of it fun. But that's all. I want to love Maas's books - but the last four (QoS, ACOMAF, EoS and now ACOWAR) have left me disappointed.

*About sex scenes in teen books - I don't think sex should be deliberately left out of teen books. But I really don't like the way Maas handles them. They are written fairly graphically (bordering on erotica), there are usually too many of them IMO, and her treatment of sexuality is not consistent or thought through enough to make the representation in these books feel appropriate for a teen audience. I googled "writing sex in teen books" to try and work out my thoughts on this topic, and some of the articles that came up were a big help, particularly the Deliciously Fictitious and Publishing Crawl ones.

title: SOME SPOILERS IF READ. Perfect third book to the ACOTAR series.
body: Where do I even begin! So many twists and turns. Love the character development of rhysand.. what a dream of a man!😮‍💨 So much death and war, for a preparation against hybern and the cauldron but OMG I was not expecting that towards the ending, what a page turner at EVERY PAGE! I had literal tears in my eyes regarding the rhysand scene thinking DO NOT DO THIS TO ME. I would have really hated that change in the story otherwise..  love the story line on Mor and Azriel, also the mating bonds forming between the most unexpected people!  Such a beautiful finish to this book, really looking forward to making a start on the next book and where it will go, especially hopefully some more character development on the sisters..

profile.name: Nicolle Hill

title: 5 Stars
body: ACOWAR is the third book in this series & yet there is still so much to uncover, understand and unveil.  Maas keeps the thrills and suspense coming right from the start. Yet another book that I couldn’t put down!  I absolutely adore the character building. We learn so much about the in-depth personalities of the found family: Mor, Azriel, Amren & Cassian, as well as seeing how Feyre adapts to her new role as High Lady ✨ I really enjoyed getting to know more about Elain & Nesta….and am hoping to learn so much more about them in future books 🤞🏻  There is so much to unpack throughout this book, with so many unexpected twists & turns which led me on an emotional rollercoaster (tears, laughter, shock, rage…repeat). This is exactly what kept me gripped from start to finish, I needed to know what was going to happen next!  The final third of the book is epic, such an amazing and climactic end.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and will continue to devour this series for every minute of every day 🖤
body_html:
ACOWAR is the third book in this series & yet there is still so much to uncover, understand and unveil.

Maas keeps the thrills and suspense coming right from the start. Yet another book that I couldn’t put down!

I absolutely adore the character building. We learn so much about the in-depth personalities of the found family: Mor, Azriel, Amren & Cassian, as well as seeing how Feyre adapts to her new role as High Lady ✨ I really enjoyed getting to know more about Elain & Nesta….and am hoping to learn so much more about them in future books 🤞🏻

There is so much to unpack throughout this book, with so many unexpected twists & turns which led me on an emotional rollercoaster (tears, laughter, shock, rage…repeat). This is exactly what kept me gripped from start to finish, I needed to know what was going to happen next!

The final third of the book is epic, such an amazing and climactic end.

I thoroughly enjoyed it and will continue to devour this series for every minute of every day 🖤

profile.name: Amazon Customer

title: Lisa has not lost her touch!
body: I often read the 2 or 3 star reviews before I buy a book, on the basis that there are too many good books waiting out there to waste time on bad ones; and having several of Lisa Jewell's books before and enjoyed them, I'll admit I was a a bit unsure about this one based on comments like 'this is not as good as her other books,' and, worse, 'she's lost her touch,' which of course can happen to writers - but I can promise you it has not happened here. This is as good as anything Ms Jewell has written before, and I'd say one of her best. 'None of This Is True' is as fast, complex and as clever as can be, and actually made me gasp out loud at a stunningly audacious 'really did not see this coming' moment early on. At first it all seems pretty par for the course - Alix is character you're not going to feel much sympathy for, with her seemingly perfect and privileged lifestyle, and Josie is the one with the hard knocks and the dead ends...and yes, while'none of this is true,' but it's not a straightforward truth-for-lies swap at all, and isn't what you might expect at all. The plots twists are just superb. In terms of a reading experience, it's all there - the usual Jewell sharp eye for detail, the nailed-it descriptions and the keen ear for dialogue, all there in spades, so very skilful, and never grates; but on top of that, the plot is clever, elegant, and my gawd, is it pacey! I read it in an afternoon. Don't believe what another reviewer said - Lisa has not lost her touch at all. Just fabulous.

profile.name: Lexi

title: A must read, dark psychological thriller! 🩸
body: 'When she doesn't like the reality of things, she finds a reality she prefers.'  This is the story of Alix Summer and Josie Fair, two women both celebrating turning 45 at the same pub. In the pub toilets, they first meet and discover they are 'birthday twin's - born on the same day. Not only that, born in the same year at the same hospital. Soon, both of their lives become intertwined and nothing will ever be the same again.  I read this book at the beginning of last week and have delayed reviewing it until now, as I just couldn't find the words to describe how much I love it! It is a dark psychological thriller, full of suspense, that only gets darker the more you read- and at certain points I would say revolting. The inclusion of podcast transcripts, social media as well as the documentary aspect all add another dimension to the story. I was gripped and on edge, uncomfortable from the beginning until the end.  It is amazing to have two female protagonists at the forefront of this story, with a particular spotlight on how social media is not an accurate reflection of someone's life and nobody knows the reality of life behind closed doors. Josie is particularly complex and unhinged. She is very odd, narsasistic, obsessive and manipulative. She really is quite terrifying! Everything she does is calculated and whilst being very unlikeable, I was totally captivated by her and I can't stop thinking about her. I loved Alix. She is a woman who wants to have it all - the career, house, marriage and family. While there where times I wanted to shake her, for her to stand her ground - in relation to both Josey and Nathan, ultimately I found her very relatable. Her love for her family and wanting to protect them, shone through everything.  This is a tale about the fragility of life and how things are never as they seem. This is my favourite Lisa Jewell book by far. I'm well and truly fascinated and want to know more! 🎧🩸

title: Gripping
body: After a chance meet whilst both Josie and Alix are celebrating their 45th birthdays, Josie becomes obsessed with the connection between them and finding ways to bump in to Alix. Josie suggests that Alix uses her as the subject for one of her podcasts with the subject of changing her life. This podcast 'birthday twins' is kept secret whilst recording, as Josie reveals her dark past beginning with her grooming by her current husband. Both Josie and Alix are great characters and we really delved into their lives. This book was fast paced and compelling. I didn't want to put it down. I alternated between kindle and audio for this and the audio book really does have the wow factor.

profile.name: Miss N. D. Jones

title: Easy read, well written, predictable
body: I suppose being predictable was a given considering the title already told us none of it was true and we found out early on someone was going to die. So that left reliance on rich character development and quality writing to provide the entertainment, which the book definitely delivers on. The Alix character became incredibly irritating very quickly but that was where we were led. I had hoped some of the themes (the denim) would have had a more complex back story - the denim curtains was just risible but the author missed an opportunity to do much with it. Several of the story lines were not very believable to me due to lack of fuller exploration but, it wasn't meant to be War and Peace. All in all it was worth the £2.99 and a perfectly decent light read.
body_html: I suppose being predictable was a given considering the title already told us none of it was true and we found out early on someone was going to die. So that left reliance on rich character development and quality writing to provide the entertainment, which the book definitely delivers on. The Alix character became incredibly irritating very quickly but that was where we were led. I had hoped some of the themes (the denim) would have had a more complex back story - the denim curtains was just risible but the author missed an opportunity to do much with it. Several of the story lines were not very believable to me due to lack of fuller exploration but, it wasn't meant to be War and Peace. All in all it was worth the £2.99 and a perfectly decent light read.
date.raw: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 March 2024
profile.name: C. Murphy

title: Anther great read from Jewel
body: Jewel never disappoints and she certainly delivers here in this brilliant holiday read, full of twists and turns that have you guessing throughout.-It's a plot of obsession, lies and murder. Alix and Josie meet by chance at a pub where they are celebrating their forty fifth birthdays. From the outside one has it all, friends, looks and fame: she produces successful podcasts while the other is full with bitterness, regrets and what could have been. After their initial introduction in the pub loos, Josie initiates another meeting whereby she offers to be the next subject on the podcast. An opportunity Alix jumps at despite her initial doubts about this rather strange woman. Josie excitingly informs her that something big is going to happen to her but first she must tell her side of her story. She begins to detail a toxic life of grooming, child abuse and domestic violence. As Alix falls deeper into her web of lies and deceit she puts her husband and family at risk and danger. Soon it is Josie calling the shots and Alix who is following blindly always one step behind. Unfortunately she realises too late just how dangerous and manipulative Josie is. Jewel's style and structure for this novel is interesting as it flips back and forth between narrative and interviews, which will contribute to a Netflix documentary series. As it progresses it captures the unraveling of Josie. highly recommend
body_html:
Jewel never disappoints and she certainly delivers here in this brilliant holiday read, full of twists and turns that have you guessing throughout.-It's a plot of obsession, lies and murder.
Alix and Josie meet by chance at a pub where they are celebrating their forty fifth birthdays. From the outside one has it all, friends, looks and fame: she produces successful podcasts while the other is full with bitterness, regrets and what could have been.
After their initial introduction in the pub loos, Josie initiates another meeting whereby she offers to be the next subject on the podcast. An opportunity Alix jumps at despite her initial doubts about this rather strange woman. Josie excitingly informs her that something big is going to happen to her but first she must tell her side of her story. She begins to detail a toxic life of grooming, child abuse and domestic violence. As Alix falls deeper into her web of lies and deceit she puts her husband and family at risk and danger. Soon it is Josie calling the shots and Alix who is following blindly always one step behind. Unfortunately she realises too late just how dangerous and manipulative Josie is.
Jewel's style and structure for this novel is interesting as it flips back and forth between narrative and interviews, which will contribute to a Netflix documentary series. As it progresses it captures the unraveling of Josie.
highly recommend

title: Spoiler alert. Well sort of.
body: I live Lisa Jewell books. So I was really looking forward to reading this. It was an OK book mostly. But I found the characters annoying and the way 2 of the characters in particular were portrayed. One is a paedophile who we are feeling sorry for (supposedly) by the end. And the other is a complete nut job who actually had a very disfunctional childhood, who we end up having no sympathy for by the end of the book?! . Only 2 real twists and not enough went into why these happened. A little disappointing overall. Easy read for some but a wee boring for me. I'm glad I waited for the price to come right down before downloading.

title: The netflix show was better
body: 🐝 His mouth captured hers, trying to show her with his kiss what he was still learning to express in words. He loved her. He worshipped her. He'd walk across fire for her 🐝  🐝 Season 2 of the Netflix show was watched and I finally caved and started reading (after buying the entire series after season 1) haha 😂 I thought that the build up for this romance was really well done 👍 and I thought that Daphne and Simon had great chemistry when they were falling in love 😍 it found it really easy to get to know the characters and was comfortable to be reading ☺️ I will admit that my cover is TV show Simon and Daphne and that is how I pictured them the entire time 🤭 although I didn’t like Daphne’s whole smart-not-really innocence 😑 and I HATED *that* scene - why would you ruin a perfectly good romance book😔 this was a good book but a bit meh after the show

profile.name: Tess

title: Jane Austen but... Steamy?!
body: I loved this book. Like commonly claimed, this book is very much Jane Austen for adults. Sprinkled liberally with sexual tension both awkward and inviting, this book is not for those more clean-minded. The historical elements were beautiful in the way that they were easily interpreted by the modern reader. It was very easy to find myself in the very same room as the characters! However, as what I might label a "Bubblegum book", it was very cringey to read at times. Like any awkward teen chick novel, you have to be in a very specific mood to overlook, or even enjoy the suffering of the characters.
body_html:
I loved this book.
Like commonly claimed, this book is very much Jane Austen for adults. Sprinkled liberally with sexual tension both awkward and inviting, this book is not for those more clean-minded.

However, as what I might label a "Bubblegum book", it was very cringey to read at times. Like any awkward teen chick novel, you have to be in a very specific mood to overlook, or even enjoy the suffering of the characters.

profile.name: Rosie Hartwell

title: Bridgerton: The Duke and l - series Book 1.
body: First of the Bridgerton series. Poor Simon had the most abdominal and unloving father a Duke. Simon grew up alone and afraid of his father which caused him to stutter. When the Duke passed away and Simon became the new Duke he chose not to marry and have children. He meets his best friend Anthony's sister Daphne and there is instant chemistry. Both are being plagued by the Georgian marriage market and both decide to pretend that they are courting. But when Anthony catches them kissing the are forced marry. With a lot of teething problems Simon and Daphne grow to love each other and to go on and have children.

profile.name: Susan Armstrong

title: Speech impediments and crazy families
body: An enjoyable read with a lot of heart, this story starts in a really poignant way. At four years old stuttering ducal heir Simon is rejected by his narcissistic father. Naturally he grows up scarred by his father's rejection.  Eldest Bridgerton daughter Daphne strikes a deal with adult Duke Simon to get matchmaking mothers off their backs. They will pretend to be besotted with each other. Romance readers will know exactly where this plot is headed. The central romance is a moving emotional voyage, and there are many funny moments thanks to the entertaining Bridgerton family.  It's a good book. I would give it 4.5 stars if I could as it didn't fully realise the potential of its enthralling beginning.
body_html:
An enjoyable read with a lot of heart, this story starts in a really poignant way. At four years old stuttering ducal heir Simon is rejected by his narcissistic father. Naturally he grows up scarred by his father's rejection.

Eldest Bridgerton daughter Daphne strikes a deal with adult Duke Simon to get matchmaking mothers off their backs. They will pretend to be besotted with each other. Romance readers will know exactly where this plot is headed. The central romance is a moving emotional voyage, and there are many funny moments thanks to the entertaining Bridgerton family.

It's a good book. I would give it 4.5 stars if I could as it didn't fully realise the potential of its enthralling beginning.
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 14 January 2016
profile.name: lisa

title: Sucked into the Bridgerton vortex
body: I felt like I was one of the few romance readers on Earth who hadn't read or watched Bridgerton and after much contemplation I decided that I would read the series and then watch the first season on Netflix. And I have to say that I am very glad I did. I fell in love with the Bridgerton clan and I'm so excited to read more books and see the remaining seven siblings get their HEAs. I did like Simon and Daphne's story and I could feel the chemistry between the two from very early on. There is one scene - which is well written about in reviews and articles so I won't bother rehashing it here - that is very unpleasant to read in the books (and unfortunately is not rectified in the TV show either) but as I was prepared it existed I was able to reconcile my distaste for what occurred and move on (which I know isn't something everyone can do). This scene is really the reason it's 3.5 stars for me (otherwise it would've been a 4/4.5) but it is what it is. I'd still recommend reading giving this book a go... especially as the later books look fantastic!!  3.5 stars
body_html:
I felt like I was one of the few romance readers on Earth who hadn't read or watched Bridgerton and after much contemplation I decided that I would read the series and then watch the first season on Netflix. And I have to say that I am very glad I did. I fell in love with the Bridgerton clan and I'm so excited to read more books and see the remaining seven siblings get their HEAs.
I did like Simon and Daphne's story and I could feel the chemistry between the two from very early on. There is one scene - which is well written about in reviews and articles so I won't bother rehashing it here - that is very unpleasant to read in the books (and unfortunately is not rectified in the TV show either) but as I was prepared it existed I was able to reconcile my distaste for what occurred and move on (which I know isn't something everyone can do). This scene is really the reason it's 3.5 stars for me (otherwise it would've been a 4/4.5) but it is what it is.
I'd still recommend reading giving this book a go... especially as the later books look fantastic!!

3.5 stars

title: All hail Julia Quinn
body: Ah Julia Quinn, you make me cry and you make me laugh till my ribs hurt. How many times I've had to take my glasses off and wipe them and my eyes I can't remember. I absolutely love these books on Lady Whistledown . I have just purchased the first of the Bridgerton series and true to form I went to bed last night with sore ribs but quite relaxed and slept well. Now that's not bad for a 79 year old insomniac suffering from chronic illness. All I need do when miserable is read one of you stories and it fixes thjngs for a while. Thank you Julia.

profile.name: Jay

title: Full of heart
body: I wasn't sure going into this book as I'd read reviews (spoiler free thank goodness, and so is this review) that said it was different to Colleen's other books. And it is. But I'm so glad I read it. It's one of those books that is going to stay with me. Lily is a beautiful person and her story is so well told, from the diary entries scattered throughout to her friendship with Alyssa and her relationship with her mother. And the romance. Ah, the romance. It's beautiful, heart stopping, heart racing, heartfelt, painful and real. I just wanted to go have a coffee with Lily, I felt like we could be best friends. And that way I could have hugged her when she needed it. My favourite thing about this book was the Naked Truths. I think we could all use them in our lives and our relationships. This book was not what I expected, but at the same time it was exactly what I expect from Colleen Hoover. It's a fantastic read! Go read it. You'll love it.

profile.name: TracyReads

title: unputdownable, but...
body: While this was an easy read in terms of writing and flow, it was very hard for me because of the content.  Climbing out of the very deep, dark hole of domestic violence (emotionally, physically, and psychologically) is one of the hardest things I've ever had to do. It is so complex, so heartbreaking, so exhausting, and very confusing. Constantly questioning yourself, your identity, your beliefs and your values. Simultaneously holding on to the "good" while also questioning why you haven't left yet. For some this may be triggering, for others it provides some insight into this issue which is much needed.  This quote from Emily May's Goodreads sums it up: "It peels back the layers of characters and relationships to do something that so many other authors have tried and failed to do - to make you understand a situation that, for most people, makes no sense. It's very sad, painful and exceptionally honest. My heart hurt while reading it, and I almost cried several times."  and from Katerina on Goodreads: "There are times I am angry and times I am sad. And then I'm both. And it's the worst because there is a war raging inside me, and the winning side keeps changing. How is it possible to switch from denial to sorrow to fury to acceptance in a heartbeat?"  and finally, this quote... something I questioned often.  “There is no such thing as bad people. We’re all just people who sometimes do bad things.”
body_html:
While this was an easy read in terms of writing and flow, it was very hard for me because of the content.

Climbing out of the very deep, dark hole of domestic violence (emotionally, physically, and psychologically) is one of the hardest things I've ever had to do. It is so complex, so heartbreaking, so exhausting, and very confusing. Constantly questioning yourself, your identity, your beliefs and your values. Simultaneously holding on to the "good" while also questioning why you haven't left yet. For some this may be triggering, for others it provides some insight into this issue which is much needed.

This quote from Emily May's Goodreads sums it up:
"It peels back the layers of characters and relationships to do something that so many other authors have tried and failed to do - to make you understand a situation that, for most people, makes no sense. It's very sad, painful and exceptionally honest. My heart hurt while reading it, and I almost cried several times."

and from Katerina on Goodreads:
"There are times I am angry and times I am sad. And then I'm both. And it's the worst because there is a war raging inside me, and the winning side keeps changing. How is it possible to switch from denial to sorrow to fury to acceptance in a heartbeat?"

and finally, this quote... something I questioned often.

“There is no such thing as bad people. We’re all just people who sometimes do bad things.”

profile.name: Trudie

title: Brilliant book
body: I put off reading this book for ages, it was in my house on the TBR pile but we all know that the TBR pile is like a big black hole!!! As soon as It Starts With Us was announced though, I preordered that and decided to wait and read them together. I am so happy with that decision and I can tell you that I devoured this in a day and was so happy that I could immediately start on It Starts With Us.  This story actually touched so close to home, I grew up in an abusive home and all I can say is that it wasn’t pretty, unlike this story though, my monster was my mother, the one person that should be protecting us. (Absolutely not looking for sympathy I’m just sharing that I can understand the fear that this book portrayed)  With that said though, I absolutely loved this book, there were so many moments that just broke my heart while I read it, but equally there were so many moments that filled me with so much love, joy and hope.  This following quote sent chills through my body.  My mother went through it, I went through it I’ll be damned if I let my daughter go through it. I kiss her on the forehead and make her a promise. It stops here, with me and you, It ends with us!!!  I have been there and had to make that same choice for the exact same reason, someone needs to break the cycle of abuse.  Atlas and Lily both live a life of abuse, both different kinds of abuse, but abuse nonetheless. As teenagers this pair were each other’s hope, each other’s rock and each other’s home, sadly of course things never turn out how we think it will and they are definitely in for a time of disappointment.  I think this storyline was told so well and after reading the authors notes at the end I can understand why.  Obviously the book wasn’t all about Lily and Atlas, we got to meet Alyssa and Marshall who were the sweetest couple ever.  Of course we then meet Ryle, Alyssa’s brother, there is a lot more to this guy than meets the eye, which is all I can say without spoiling too much.  Absolutely brilliant read that I wholeheartedly recommend.
body_html:
I put off reading this book for ages, it was in my house on the TBR pile but we all know that the TBR pile is like a big black hole!!! As soon as It Starts With Us was announced though, I preordered that and decided to wait and read them together. I am so happy with that decision and I can tell you that I devoured this in a day and was so happy that I could immediately start on It Starts With Us.

This story actually touched so close to home, I grew up in an abusive home and all I can say is that it wasn’t pretty, unlike this story though, my monster was my mother, the one person that should be protecting us. (Absolutely not looking for sympathy I’m just sharing that I can understand the fear that this book portrayed)

With that said though, I absolutely loved this book, there were so many moments that just broke my heart while I read it, but equally there were so many moments that filled me with so much love, joy and hope.

This following quote sent chills through my body.

My mother went through it,
I went through it
I’ll be damned if I let my daughter go through it.
I kiss her on the forehead and make her a promise.
It stops here, with me and you, It ends with us!!!

I have been there and had to make that same choice for the exact same reason, someone needs to break the cycle of abuse.

Atlas and Lily both live a life of abuse, both different kinds of abuse, but abuse nonetheless. As teenagers this pair were each other’s hope, each other’s rock and each other’s home, sadly of course things never turn out how we think it will and they are definitely in for a time of disappointment.

I think this storyline was told so well and after reading the authors notes at the end I can understand why.

Obviously the book wasn’t all about Lily and Atlas, we got to meet Alyssa and Marshall who were the sweetest couple ever.

Of course we then meet Ryle, Alyssa’s brother, there is a lot more to this guy than meets the eye, which is all I can say without spoiling too much.

Absolutely brilliant read that I wholeheartedly recommend.
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 26 October 2022
profile.name: Caz the bookworm /Caroline O'Sullivan

title: Both loved and hated it at the same time
body: Let me start by saying my 15 yr old daughter recommended this book to me. As a mother of two daughters I’ve spent their whole lives so far being very open and honest with them both about all things in life. The good, the bad and the ugly. I find it important to teach my girls about all things in life and not just the good stuff. We talk about relationships, friends, partners, sex, drugs, alcohol, love, money, school, banking, mortgages, the works. Anything and everything you can think of. My eldest daughter loves to read so when I come across a book that I feel shows the uglier sides of life, written in a way the is relatable to normally recommend for her to read it. It has become a good opening to conversations. So when she recommended I read this book. I brought it without thinking. She didn’t tell me what it was about, but it has now become a talking point for us.  Your authors note was just about as heart breaking as the story. I’m with you when you said you wanting to delete and start again. That you fell in love with Ryle. It was heartbreaking so read what he was doing. I felt the pain for both of them. But I think you were right in writing their story the way you did. The more these things are talked about, the more someone who hasn’t been in that position and start to understand, the more help there will be from normal everyday friends and family for people who end up in Lily’s position. And hopefully over time we can all help to break the cycle of things like this.  Thank you for your words, for helping to be a conversation starter.

Your authors note was just about as heart breaking as the story. I’m with you when you said you wanting to delete and start again. That you fell in love with Ryle. It was heartbreaking so read what he was doing. I felt the pain for both of them. But I think you were right in writing their story the way you did. The more these things are talked about, the more someone who hasn’t been in that position and start to understand, the more help there will be from normal everyday friends and family for people who end up in Lily’s position. And hopefully over time we can all help to break the cycle of things like this.

Thank you for your words, for helping to be a conversation starter.

profile.name: Cliente Kindle

title: This story of love, friendship, heartache, strength and hope is one I loved reading
body: I am giving "It ends with us" 5 amazing stars!!!  Colleen you've done it again!  We meet Lily at the age of 15, she becomes a lifeline to Atlas a young boy who has found himself homeless. Lily shows him kindness, love and hope when no one else did.  I fell in love with Lily, she was not only her mothers protector when her father became abusive but she became Atlas's Angel when life seemed to hard to go on.  Atlas, had nothing, other than the clothes on his back and his backpack he had nothing. He came to live in the deserted house behind Lily's home and it was at this point she saved him.  Lily meets Ryle once she's grown up, living in Boston. Their first meeting is unexpected but sets the path to their relationship. Months later, they meet again, there relationship blossoms and somehow even though they've had different ideas of what they want out of a relationship it seems to work well for both of them.  Lily meets Alyssa when she's starting her own business. Alyssa is a breath of fresh air and is just what Lily needs! I love the friendship these two have and even after Lily finds out Ryle is Alyssa's brother doesn't change the love and support these two offer each other. I loved Alyssa and the strength she gave Lily and the friendship these two have would withstand the toughest of situations.  Lily had a strength about her that I admired. Having lived in an abusive home she was adamant she would not allow herself to follow in her mothers foot steps. This story of love, friendship, heartache, strength and hope is one I loved reading. I didn't want to out it down.  I want to say thank you to Colleen Hoover for writing this. Leaving a partner, husband, wife, boyfriend or girlfriend in an abusive relationship is never an easy one. I too have a great respect and admiration for my mother who left my father due to an abusive relationship. She not only saved herself but myself and my two sisters.  I loved this book with all my heart. 5 well earned stars from me!  #readingtigress #colleenhoover #itendswithus #5stars
body_html:
I am giving "It ends with us" 5 amazing stars!!!

Colleen you've done it again!

We meet Lily at the age of 15, she becomes a lifeline to Atlas a young boy who has found himself homeless. Lily shows him kindness, love and hope when no one else did.

I fell in love with Lily, she was not only her mothers protector when her father became abusive but she became Atlas's Angel when life seemed to hard to go on.

Atlas, had nothing, other than the clothes on his back and his backpack he had nothing. He came to live in the deserted house behind Lily's home and it was at this point she saved him.

Lily meets Ryle once she's grown up, living in Boston. Their first meeting is unexpected but sets the path to their relationship. Months later, they meet again, there relationship blossoms and somehow even though they've had different ideas of what they want out of a relationship it seems to work well for both of them.

Lily meets Alyssa when she's starting her own business. Alyssa is a breath of fresh air and is just what Lily needs! I love the friendship these two have and even after Lily finds out Ryle is Alyssa's brother doesn't change the love and support these two offer each other. I loved Alyssa and the strength she gave Lily and the friendship these two have would withstand the toughest of situations.

Lily had a strength about her that I admired. Having lived in an abusive home she was adamant she would not allow herself to follow in her mothers foot steps. This story of love, friendship, heartache, strength and hope is one I loved reading. I didn't want to out it down.

I want to say thank you to Colleen Hoover for writing this. Leaving a partner, husband, wife, boyfriend or girlfriend in an abusive relationship is never an easy one. I too have a great respect and admiration for my mother who left my father due to an abusive relationship. She not only saved herself but myself and my two sisters.

I loved this book with all my heart. 5 well earned stars from me!

#readingtigress #colleenhoover #itendswithus #5stars
date.raw: Reviewed in Australia on 7 August 2016
profile.name: Melanie Zerafa

title: Heartbreaking
body: This was heartbreaking to read. Lily grew up in an abusive household. Although he never touched her, her father beat her mother and Lily often put herself in between them. She couldn’t understand why her mother didn’t leave. Then she meets and falls in love with Ryle, and just when she thinks that she has everything she could wish for, he hits her. She has to decide if she can forgive him and move forward. And just to make matters more complicated, since running into her first love again unexpectedly, she can’t help wondering how things could have been different. This was such a hard read - what I thought to be so black and white has so many grey areas, and I ended up feeling torn by the decisions Lily makes and wishing things not to play out as they did! It also made me feel very grateful. I would recommend the read but it comes with a trigger warning. It was so well written and I wasn’t surprised to learn at the end that it based on the author’s true experience.
body_html:
This was heartbreaking to read.
Lily grew up in an abusive household. Although he never touched her, her father beat her mother and Lily often put herself in between them. She couldn’t understand why her mother didn’t leave.
Then she meets and falls in love with Ryle, and just when she thinks that she has everything she could wish for, he hits her.
She has to decide if she can forgive him and move forward. And just to make matters more complicated, since running into her first love again unexpectedly, she can’t help wondering how things could have been different.
This was such a hard read - what I thought to be so black and white has so many grey areas, and I ended up feeling torn by the decisions Lily makes and wishing things not to play out as they did! It also made me feel very grateful.
I would recommend the read but it comes with a trigger warning. It was so well written and I wasn’t surprised to learn at the end that it based on the author’s true experience.

title: we hate Ryle
body: SPOILERS‼️‼️this book was not a romance, this book was a story about a woman experiencing the troubles of blind love and not being able to fully leave someone even if they are abusive. This book was good but I didn’t see what all the hype was about and the fact that people were using the romantic scenes in the novel to represent this book when on reality it’s not a romance is quite disturbing. I think we can all agree that lily deserves a better life,she should find a nice little ocean view house and keep swimming far far away from Ryle.

profile.name: Jenna

title: Just Keep Swimming....
body: It Ends With Us surprised me. A different read of Colleen Hoover’s, one written direct from the heart. My heart was really torn reading those book for many reasons. I felt for Lily, I felt for Atlas, I felt for Ryle and I felt for Lily’s mum. This book really made me sit back and think about what I would do, in her situation. What’s right and what’s wrong and in whose opinion?  Lily’s strength to make the right decision not just for her but for others on her life is remarkable, though sometimes I just wanted to shake her, but I loved reading about her teenage years and her 24 year old self. When life got tough, she just ‘kept on swimming’ hoping every wave led her to happiness and the right decisions.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book, I really just could have kept reading!
body_html:
It Ends With Us surprised me. A different read of Colleen Hoover’s, one written direct from the heart. My heart was really torn reading those book for many reasons. I felt for Lily, I felt for Atlas, I felt for Ryle and I felt for Lily’s mum. This book really made me sit back and think about what I would do, in her situation. What’s right and what’s wrong and in whose opinion?

Lily’s strength to make the right decision not just for her but for others on her life is remarkable, though sometimes I just wanted to shake her, but I loved reading about her teenage years and her 24 year old self. When life got tough, she just ‘kept on swimming’ hoping every wave led her to happiness and the right decisions.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book, I really just could have kept reading!

Overall, it is a good read, but hasn't stayed with me - didn't give me anything to take away from it. It wasn't one of those books that you read and it stays with you and you crave to stay in that world and with the characters - for me, it was a eh, read it, it's over. Next book.

body: This opening alone, without even the author's name attached is a one click!  "As I sit here with one foot on either side of the ledge looking down.." If only every book opened this way.  Told trough Lilly's POV, her story, this book is both beautifully written, heart breaking and real. It's also something you need to be in the correct mindset to read, content warnings might be absent, but it's not as sweet as the cover suggests. Life never is.  The missing star - it felt rushed. Detailed, emotional, then rushed in the last moments.

profile.name: Brigette Sigley

title: Fair warning: This book will make you cry!
body: I have loved every Colleen Hoover book I have read and this one did not disappoint. My neighbour recommended I read Colleens latest book and as I was in a bit of a book slump I decided to give it a go. It'd been a year or more since I picked up one of her books and I will be reading and rereading her books over the next week. I devoured this story in 5-6 hours and could not put it down. I laughed and cried and I cried some more. Lilly and Ryle are such fabulous characters and I hurt for both of them. I can only imagine how hard it would be to write a story centering around domestic violence and to do it so well, but Colleen has done such an amazing job. Congratulations on such a wonderful book, I look forward to reading more.

title: From Soul Crushing to Enlightening
body: A must read!!! Colleen Hoover has done exceptionally well with "IT ENDS WITH US" Those 4 words that I myself have uttered and professed to live my life by.. The events of my past Now End with ME!!!  THE CYCLE STOPS HERE IN THIS MOMENT!!!  As it did with Lily Bloom and so many others before, alongside, and with her. I commend Colleen for writing such a poignant and prolific book that had me feeling the up's and down's of this novel (My Hard Copy arrived from Amazon today) Love has it's limit that is such a prolific message in this novel.. and how far will you compromise yourself for love.. is it until you have no limits left.. I cried big fat salty tears, they fell like the teardrops they were, I sobbed... and I loved... and in the end I healed...  A Must Read... your soul will be forever changed ... when you absorb the messages and gifts this book holds xx💖xx

title: Emotional
body: It’s not very often you come across books that have you in tears and feeling all kinds of things. But I feel like every time I read a Colleen Hoover book that’s exactly what happens! This book was a very rocky and emotional ride for me, it’s so well written and you can’t help but feel that you are the main character in the book and it’s you who’s living through it. Another great book from the author can not recommend enough!

profile.name: Rhianne Wilson

title: just finished this - going to have the biggest book hangover
body: Ok wow.  This is a must read for anyone who ever has been or will be in a romantic relationship. It's one of those rare books with an important message that is still enjoyable to read. It was hard in moments, definitely, but I also laughed and loved along with the characters.  I didn't read any reviews or the blurb - I loved 'slammed' and 'November 9' so as soon as I saw it was Colleen Hoover I was in. So I had no idea what to expect - which I think is the perfect way to experience this book. To go on the journey with the character. To fall in love with the characters without the preconceptions of knowing what will happen further on.  So no spoilers from me. Read this book, it is brave and bold, it is dark and funny at times, sweet and romantic at others, and bitter and hopeful all at the same time.

profile.name: Rosalie

title: Falling
body: This story will draw you into a world that's often misunderstood and misrepresented by society. You will fall in love with the protagonist and feel intense emotions that will cause your heart to contemplate the issues of love and passion as she finds herself falling in love with the perfect man who is ultimately flawed just like everyone else. What character flaws are acceptable and what character flaws are unacceptable are explored in depth. Wave after wave of the people who shape our hearts and therefore our perspective will challenge your heart. Falling in love and remaining in love are truly distinguished by the choices we make along the journey. That's what I was able to receive reading this truly naked truth tale of love.

profile.name: Beyond the Pages Charli

title: Is there an Us?  4.5*
body: This is about Lily, Atlas, the homeless boy she saved & then the new man in her life Ryle. The latter was focussed on his career & a non committed life. It was one of those Insta attraction moments for both. But what happens if your past collides with your present?  Do you really know someone? So if you've been the victim of an abusive relationship that often turns out to be the case esp from first impressions. I must admit Ryle did show us his real side then but like many others I don't want to believe the way the course of their lives changed. I know this is done so authors can tell their story. (Don't get me wrong I didn't condone his actions OK !)  I also feel there wasn't enough of Adam in the latter part of the story. It just lacked something for me before it became more.  After all the drama, Lily's ending was one we have to assume worked out for her but it ended too abruptly for me. I don't like being left hanging without it all being tied up. But this is a work of fiction & it's one we have to deal with.
body_html:
This is about Lily, Atlas, the homeless boy she saved & then the new man in her life Ryle. The latter was focussed on his career & a non committed life. It was one of those Insta attraction moments for both. But what happens if your past collides with your present?

Do you really know someone? So if you've been the victim of an abusive relationship that often turns out to be the case esp from first impressions. I must admit Ryle did show us his real side then but like many others I don't want to believe the way the course of their lives changed. I know this is done so authors can tell their story. (Don't get me wrong I didn't condone his actions OK !)

I also feel there wasn't enough of Adam in the latter part of the story. It just lacked something for me before it became more.

After all the drama, Lily's ending was one we have to assume worked out for her but it ended too abruptly for me. I don't like being left hanging without it all being tied up. But this is a work of fiction & it's one we have to deal with.

title: Psychological masterpiece
body: A book that will open your eyes in what decades of research has been suggesting about the inconsistencies in human behaviour. The author goes into tremendous detail to explain the thought patterns of our minds.  A downside is that the book is printed in miniature font, which slightly worsened the reading experience. You're also likely to lose interest in the author's argument over time reading this book unless you show some degree of passion or enthusiasm about behavioural psychology.

profile.name: Macsking

title: System 1 is just like our intuitive thinking
body: This book is incredible for discussing the rationality of human beings. Human behaviors are not only irrational, but also predictably irrational, which is the main topic of this book. This book has divided into 5 main topics, and discussed three different pairs of concepts. The first one is our thinking system, one is fast (denoted as system 1), another is slow (denoted as system 2). System 1 is just like our intuitive thinking, and system 2 is like deliberate thinking. Many of our irrational behaviors are caused by the fast response of system 1, together with the laziness of system 2. The second pair is Humans and Econs, which Econ means the rational assumption assumed by classic economists, and Human means the actual human in the daily life. The Prospect Theory is used explained in what kinds of situation that humans do not behave like economists have predicted, and why. The third pair is the experiencing self and remembering self. The feeling we experience during the events is very different than the the feelings in our memory, which sometimes cause decision making not as make sense and let us regret later. Overall this book is full of insightful thoughts, with a lot of examples to explain the concepts. Daniel Kahneman did a great job on all these topics
body_html:
This book is incredible for discussing the rationality of human beings. Human behaviors are not only irrational, but also predictably irrational, which is the main topic of this book.
This book has divided into 5 main topics, and discussed three different pairs of concepts. The first one is our thinking system, one is fast (denoted as system 1), another is slow (denoted as system 2). System 1 is just like our intuitive thinking, and system 2 is like deliberate thinking. Many of our irrational behaviors are caused by the fast response of system 1, together with the laziness of system 2.
The second pair is Humans and Econs, which Econ means the rational assumption assumed by classic economists, and Human means the actual human in the daily life. The Prospect Theory is used explained in what kinds of situation that humans do not behave like economists have predicted, and why.
The third pair is the experiencing self and remembering self. The feeling we experience during the events is very different than the the feelings in our memory, which sometimes cause decision making not as make sense and let us regret later.
Overall this book is full of insightful thoughts, with a lot of examples to explain the concepts. Daniel Kahneman did a great job on all these topics
